author: Kevin Maggio

text: Sorry, but this video is total bullshit. All you've done is provide advertisements for a handful of proposed technologies without addressing how much these plants capture compared to annual CO2 emissions, and how they'll be powered if not by fossil fuel themselves. If you had done that, you'd come to the conclusions that millions of these plants would be required just to set our effective emissions to zero, and that's still leaving all the carbon in the atmosphere we've emitted since industrialization. The biggest single plant of this kind captures 4,000 tonnes annually. We emit 35 BILLION tonnes annually, meaning you'd need almost nine million of these carbon capture plants. Not only that, but you didn't mention that these technologies require energy to produce and power, and where are you going to get that energy when almost all of our power comes from fossil fuels? Carbon capture is a bullshit technology. The ONLY solution is scaling down our energy demands. That means fewer commodities for everyone. Period.

author: Col Sylvester

text:
I believe carbon capture is a very important solution. As a product and a service. Climeworks captures carbon from the ambient air in Hinwil/Switzerland and sells it as a product to a vegetable producer who feeds it into the greenhouse a few hundred meters besides the capture infrastructure (It is just beside the Sauber F1 head quarters). The problem with CCS is that many might think of it as a get out of jail free card or a "no regret - all you can eat diet pill". 

CCS MUST have a safe end-storage solution! With a solid end-storage, you might be able to motivate people to have a storage location in their neighborhood. Climeworks claims two years until the liquid CO2 solidifies in Iceland.

I believe you should emphasize that good CCS is the only real carbon-negative solution - trees are not - and I like trees, yet they are merely a carbon storage. I also like the concrete carbon storage product! Very nice - if true

My old university (go Crimson!) got a government contract to do some basic Geo-Engineering research - and all our sustainability professors think this is an uncontrollable pandora's box...so do I.... some engineers decide who gets rain and who doesn't - if they can somewhat control it. 

Yet the most underrated solution to a turn around in sustainability is easily energy efficiency. Already in 2013, MIT Prof. John Sterman opened the MIT Sustainability Summit with "All the technology for a 100 % sustainable life style exists today"
author: Ulrich Suter

text:
Â @Col SylvesterÂ  Developing "solutions" to KEEP the existing fleet of marine & aero ships is retrograde thinking.
-> While it is true "planes" simply "do not work" with ~current~ Lithium Ion battery technology (they will in a few years), it is already not the case for ships.
  
Because there is so much money already invested on ships that COULD keep working for another 30, 50 or 70 years more (needing less money for repairs than making new ones); there is little incentive to REPLACE the diesel engines with electric motors and MASSIVE, permanent battery storage.
-> It also introduces aditional steps & infraestructure requirements on ports for the recharging of such massive the batteries (cooling down the systems is trivial by itself, but it does also raise the temperature of local waters); compared with simple pumping of fuel.
  
Because INTERNATIONAL trade is made outside of countries, the only way for companies to be FORCED to change their fleets is by blocking them (literally shooting and sinking the ships if they TRY to enter in banned national waters) in so many places they can not simply "shift the bussiness" to another place & still be rentable.
author: Argamis (SilverComet)

text: Â @Argamis (SilverComet)Â  I certainly don't mean that this should be a long term solution but waiting for other solutions to replace aviation and maritime fuels doesn't stop us digging up fossil fuels in the meantime.  The US navy has a tried and tested solution that has been shown to work and could be worth investigating for upscaling.  The power density of batteries  to fly a transatlantic craft is a long way off. I think we can all agree.  As you say, there's no incentive to replace diesel engines, so let's not.  Let's fuel them with cleaner fuel versions (the navy example means you can actually design cleaner fuels), and have an artificial carbon cycle that means we recycle the carbon, rather than adding to the biosphere carbon load by burning fossils.  It could also free countries that don't have their own fossil resources from the OPEC and global price variability.  Hawaii has (and still does?) and island nations import diesel for base load electricity in some cases.  The energy supply of any nation is more resilient with a diverse energy source mix.  I'm not discounting renewables but a nuanced approach that can work now means we can tackle climate change sooner rather than later. Thanks

text:
The is a total solution that is better than everything listed in your video, but trying to get anyone to listen seems near impossible...

We are now suffering from global heating, which means that we have a vast quantity of undesirable thermal energy....
We can create massive pipelines that suck air in at one end, and absorbs heat all along its path (surface based shallow geothermal). this gives us an air supply and a boat load of energy. Add to this ALL energy created by all forms of renewable. All of this air and energy gets directed at a factory designed to be a liquid air battery. However, this new liquid air battery storage that comes very close to lithium for power density required that we compress and cool air to a certain point..That point is far beyond the liquifying point of co2. So basically, in turning all of our renewable energy into stored liquid air, we get to remove 100% of the co2 into liquid form completely free as a byproduct!!!

We can then use this pure, clean liquid co2 to replace all other forms of liquid co2 production for commercial use (fizzy drinks e.t.c) and the rest can be stored in thinwall tanks.
We can use it mainly for co2 enrichment of carbon sequestering plants and trees that we can then compost and turn into beautiful soil to replace all of the damaged and eroded soil we have destroyed using modern agriculture globally. which will also allow us to increase the planets arable land which will allow us to grow even more food and forests and carbon sequestration.

Also, the liquid air can be used in new ways based on old technologies. We can replace fully electric cars and hybrid cars with liquid air hybrids. The liquid air can power a Nicola Tesla Turbine that can produce electricity for the electric vehicle. And we only need a small battery for acceleration and power smoothing and as such it can be made from far simpler, more common materials that are greener and more recyclable, such as the Edison battery or a more modern version...Eco friendly is more important than energy density. Liquid air is the future and we get DAC built in for free.


Please. someone, anyone. If you can see how this big picture can work on a planetary scale. make it happen or tell someone that can! Im just a lowly vagrant and have no ability to make stuff like this happen.

text:
Â @theDubleDÂ  I skimmed through it. I had already seen it Via 'Just Have a Think' weeks ago. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tMLu9Dtw9yI&.
This is exactly what I am talking about. Except that co2 seems to be an after thought, when this could become the prime method of direct air capture...And also no one anywhere seems to be bothering with the idea of Surface based geothermal to power such a factory. It is a crying shame. Normal shallow geothermal can absorb heat from about 6 meters below the earth for a constant trickle of energy and is used in some homes. But actually putting it on the surface so it is directly exposed to the air and sunlight allows such a system to capture the excessive heat that is caused by global warming and heat waves.
We already use about 2.1 million miles of pipelines for oil and gas, so any 'eyesore' or production issues type arguments are null and void.

If a 10' hose pipe left in the sun for a while can heat the water inside enough to burn, then imagine what millions of miles of pipeline can capture.
Its almost like Judo. We can literally use Global warming to combat Global warming...

text: Just Grow more trees
author: MrVatican Rag

text:
Â @MrVatican RagÂ   Oh how I wish it were that simple. Do not get me wrong, I am a hippy at heart and would love to see an entire world that is lush wild forest and other biomes suitable for the local wildlife to flourish. I would be more than happy to live in an underground cave system even and leave the surface for nature. My entire life is geared towards getting land and turning it into a permaculture food forest...

That said, we have some serious issues. Even if the entire planet decided to go with that plan..We are producing a mind numbing amount of carbon every year, we are also producing a stupid amount of new humans each year too. The Arctic has now officially become a source of carbon rather than a sink and the Amazon is virtually at its tipping point towards Forest death. Not only that, The Arctic is now suffering the worst ice melt ever seen in human existence, beating all previous records including the great el nino melt of 2012.
The very soil in which we would want to grow those trees is also dying  

"The world has lost a third of its arable land due to erosion or pollution in the past 40 years, with potentially disastrous consequences as global demand for food soars, scientists have warned.

New research has calculated that nearly 33% of the worldâ€™s adequate or high-quality food-producing land has been lost at a rate that far outstrips the pace of natural processes to replace diminished soil.

The University of Sheffieldâ€™s Grantham Centre for Sustainable Futures, which undertook the study by analysing various pieces of research published over the past decade, said the loss was â€œcatastrophicâ€ and the trend close to being irretrievable without major changes to agricultural practices."

Very soon at current levels of biosphere decay, we will not even be able to keep planted trees alive. The masses simply do not understand that for the last half a century, climate change was miniscule, but exponential. We are now at the point that each new doubling of trouble will be massive and noticable. And in the blink of an eye it will be devastating to our every day life and civilization will not be able to continue as normal.

Yes we need to rewild the entire planet, but for it to survive, we need to shrink as a species, shrink our consumption and level of luxury and incentivise as many humans as possible into growing food and trees and other crops suited to rapid sequestration as new soil. The economy and business as usual will collapse, but with so many humans growing food and lumber, we might all be broke, but we will have full bellies and a roof over our head during the transition...And while we still have an advanced civilization that is capable of mobilization, the rest of our industry should be all hands on deck providing direct air capture and transitioning to 100% renewable and recyclable everything.

text: random comment do www.projectvesta.org next.  it traps emissions perhaps in a much better way.  I am a fellow citizen journalist at cleanttechnica.com  if you want to collaborate let me know.  I am a retired (disabled) science teacher and full-time environmental advocate.  not quite an expert but I do what I can to educate others on climate change specifically renewable energy and the economics of renewable energy.  I think to not have plan b-z for the coming climate catastrophe is inane.  as an environmental advocate, I think it's important that you do what you are doing.  the environmental community has to have hope to succeed.  too many of us fall into nihilism.  its a tough call, but I think its important to selectively talk about negative emissions.  its a high debatable issue full of nuance, but what can we actually do?  the powers that be are not doing enough.  the scientific community needs to have multiple contingency plans, and I disagree with the common view of many environmentalists who think we should not even discuss negative emissions.  I respect your work and hope you will continue getting these ideas to your audience, which I feel is the perfect target audience.   Do I want the concept of negative emissions on the front page of every major media?  I am not sure exactly, probably not.  however, I think it must at least be discussed with a narrower audience.  it's hard to know what are next step forward is, science and technology are evolving so fast.  I would like to share this article of mine with you.  it discusses the ideas similar to this conversation.  I have been researching negative emissions, but have yet to cover it.  I think I will soon.  https://cleantechnica.com/2018/05/10/we-will-prevent-catastrophic-climate-change/

text:
I think its a complete waste of time.  The earth is observably greening.  CO2 imparts drought resistance to plants, this is well documented.  When the earth is warmer than today, most of the large deserts give way to grassland and forest, only the southwestern US gets drier.  These states are well documented...and the models, which all use radically different input assumptions, are clearly incorrect.  And of course, rice, a staple for much of the world, grows far faster in a high CO2 environment.  

In the end, its entirely unnecessary to scrub CO2 from the air.  All we would need to do is drastically reduce emissions.  There are some easy outs, but ironically they've been vilified.  That's because this isn't a movement based on logic and reason.  Its an ideology, a nature cult often bound up with unrealistic dreams of a socialist paradise that can never come.  Otherwise what we'd do, is start fracking like crazy to get at all of that cleaner burning methane, causing an immediate drop in emissions.  And then we'd transition to nuclear, using the fracked gas for peaking plants.

But again, an ideology, and an unhinged one at that.  They push wind/solar, which would take 5x the labor/materials of nuclear and which would actually cause far more pollution...and that's before we have to build the massive battery bank that's over 100X larger than the capacity all the batteries than have ever been built on earth.  And then they tell us "we can do it without any sacrifices.  All we have to do is..." and then follow with the long list of sacrifices.

author: Ulrich Suter

text: Â @Ulrich SuterÂ  I would not refer to the 97% consensus, if I were you. Looking at the methodology, it shows a horrendous way of creating statistics.  But let's not discuss this by referring to the degree of consensus. IPCC shows that we had several warm periods over the last 6-8000 years, and the most recent one 800 years ago. This fact is undisputed. The CO2 levels at those times were significantly lower than now.  Did you know that the arctic ice was melting at an alarming pace around 1900?  At less than 300 ppm..  Did you know that U.S. and Soviet scientists were very worried about the coming of a new Ice age, in the mid 1970's ? We had a record heat period in the start of the 1930's. We had a cooling period from the mid 1940's to the end of the 1970's and most graphs brought forward by the concerned, but misled public, starts around 1981, which was the start of the upturn after the cooling period. So how do you find the correlation between CO2 and temperature, during these periodical swings?  And which scientists do you listen to? The ones saying CO2 is the villain, and we will all drown within the next 30 years? Global sea levels have increased at a steady rate since 1850.  Someone seems to be pushing a political agenda.   Although I am all in favor of reducing pollution, it is better to concentrate on that task, by transitioning from coal/gas fired plants to Thorium reactors. That is the intelligent solution.  Solar and Wind power suffer huge disadvantages in terms of intermittency and power density. (Solar requires 450 times more land to produce the same amount as a nuclear power plant) . CCUS can not save the planet from global warming, as CO2 does not play the role which is the prerequisite for such a solution.

text:
The choice, however, isn't between a coal plant running and a coal plant running with a CCS retrofit.  Since coal-fired power stations are very uneconomic these days, the choice is generally between a coal plant running with a CCS retrofit and a coal plant that has been shut down and replaced with cheaper alternatives.

The 45Q subsidy is extremely hefty - of the order of $4 per MWh - and is hence a subsidy for coal to keep on emitting the carbon dioxide that evades capture (_at least_ 10% plus 1/3 for the energy consumption of the CCS process, even assuming the never-before-demonstrated-at-this-kind-of-scale-or-efficiency technology works as advertised for a 90% capture rate).

text:
What about the balance between reducing our carbon footprint and global dimming?
Given that global dimming, according to the IPCC report, is adding cooling as high as 0.5c, how do we square this circle?
CO2 stays in the atmosphere for hundreds of years, aerosols that result in global dimming, for a matter of weeks to months.

In other words, as we decrease our CO2 emissions, the amount of aerosols in the atmosphere reduce and hence, the overall heating of the planet climbs.

If we look at the equation of the length that CO2 stays in the atmosphere vs. aerosols ... it is clear that global dimming and a reduction in CO2 is a very real problem.

So, this makes CO2 capture an essential part of the mix of, well, saving us all from a horrific future.

text:
Every year we add around 48-49 billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent that the natural world can not sequester. Spending insane amounts on extracting and manufacturing to filter the exhausts of one or two businesses is largely a useless exercise to allow a continuation of fossil fuel burning. One comment here basically says "Soon it will be too hot/dry for trees", CC is useless without already being carbon neutral, the idea had always been to get to net zero and capture carbon, because 2.5-3 degrees will still be difficult to avoid. 

Leaving 50-75% of agricultural land to return to natural succession, not planting forest, is the easiest reduction prior to shutting down internal combustion engines, easily done by switching to a globally plant-based diet. Every recent study has shown that this is the most reliable way to restore water retention and sink carbon. The most conservative models showing 20% of our annual emissions would be removed by this alone.

text:
My concern is the long term, So if we end up cutting emissions and get super efficient at retrieving CO2 from the atmosphere, how is that going to affect the planet once we revert the atmosphere to below the original pre-industrial level.  Because then we'll have to stop trying to suck it all up and find new ways to release it again.

Plant life and everything else which relying on plant life requires a minimum level of CO2 to be sustainable.  While what we have now is an excessively high concentration, we also need to keep at least some around so that it doesn't become too low.


I understand there is also a move towards reducing methane emissions in order to reduce the weather pattern changes over a short period as methane breaks down in a decade compared to the much longer life of CO2.

text: Carbon Dioxide is not a greenhouse gas. It is a dipole molecule with a dipole moment of zero. Just the same as O2 which also has a DPM of zero. A gas molecule must have a non-zero DPM to absorb IR/UV energy. Water vapor is the greatest contributor to the greenhouse affect, which is not permanent or cumulative since trapped heat returns to space (The colder body) There is no "Climate Emergency" and human emissions do not and *CANNOT* affect climate. The entire push to capture CO2 to reverse climate change is fabricated and ludicrous. The intent of Climate Change is to tax Americans energy use to to point it is not longer affordable to constrain free-market Capitalism and promote Socialism.

text:
Richard C. Willson, Principal Investigator in charge of NASAâ€™s ACRIM series of Sun-monitoring Total Solar Irradiance satellite experiments (U.S.A.):



â€œContrary to the findings of the IPCC, scientific observations in recent decades have demonstrated that there is no â€˜climate change crisisâ€™. The concept thatâ€™s devolved into the failed CO2 anthropogenic global warming (CAGW) hypothesis is based on the flawed predictions of imprecise 1980â€™s vintage global circulation models that have failed to match observational data both since and prior to their fabrication.

The Earthâ€™s climate is determined primarily by the radiation it receives from the Sun. The amount of solar radiation the Earth receives has natural variabilities caused by both variations in the intrinsic amount of radiation emitted by the Sun and by variations in the Earth-Sun geometry caused by planetary rotational and orbital variations. Together these natural variations cause the Total Solar Irradiance (TSI) at the Earth to vary cyclically on a number of known periodicities that are synchronized with known past climatic changes.â€

text:
Â @DundorilÂ  In 1978, the Nimbus-7 satellite provided evidence of variations in Total Solar Irradiance.  Additional observations were made with an active cavity radiometer on the Solar Maximum Mission, launched in 1980. Both of these missions showed that the passage of sunspots across the Sunâ€™s disk influenced TSI. 
According to NASA Total Solar Irradiance has been building since exactly 1880. This 120 years of solar output increase was so active and so sunspot-productive that it was designated as a Grand Solar MAXIMUM which was the strongest maxima of the past 4,000 years, and low and behold global average temperatures rose with it. How unusual. Since 1755 we have had 25 solar cycles and are now in cycle 26.This is the natural variabilty of the Sun's TSI and the Earths orbital position in relation to the Sun is the main driver of  Earth's global temperature and climate change not Co2 emissions human or otherwise.

author: Vance Gilbert

text:
CO2 Capture at high concentration outlets is great and necessary but Direct Air Capture is a pipe dream that is unlikely to ever work. 

This is because you need to flow an insane amount of air through a DAC plant to capture enough CO2 to make a dent in global emissions. For example, you need to flow on the order of 1 quadrillion cubic meters of air through a DAC plant at 100% removal efficiency to pull out ~1% of our current yearly global emissions.

text:
I don't think much of carbon capture. 
Putting CO2 into products just releases it back into the atmosphere later. That's a terrible idea. Collecting CO2, breaking it down and reassembling it back into fuels and plastics makes better sense, although that seems to break the 2nd Law of Thermodynamics. I suspect the energy required to convert back into fuel would be more than the energy of the fuel you'd recover.
Like it or not, and I don't, the interim solution is nuclear energy, not renewable energy. Renewable energy is dependent on natural conditions making it unreliable. Renewables are also dependent on batteries which turn into toxic waste when their lifetime is spent. Nuclear has a smaller environmental impact in terms of mining, processing and waste products. If Tokamac or similar fusion ever becomes a thing, renewables and carbon will go by the wayside.

text:
MATT FERRELL -- Carbon Capture is an ABOMINATION.

text:
MATT FERRELL -- This video is EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTING.  There are TWO MAJOR WRONG CONCEPTS that you present.  
^^ -- First, carbon dioxide gas is NOT WARMING the Earth.  You need to pay attention to VOLCANOES and SUPERVOLCANOES under the surface.  Over 20 major volcanoes have blown since April 2018.  There are massive supervolcanoes under Siberia along the Arctic rim and under New England, per geologists.  
^^ -- Greenhouse Effect in the atmosphere is primarily due to CLOUDS and HUMIDITY.
^^ -- A molecule's REACH for capturing incident heat photons is limited to the electron orbiting radius of its second highest stable orbit.  The highest stable orbit is where the electron jumps when it absorbs the photon.  If it absorbs the photon at the highest orbit, the electron takes off, ionizing the molecule.
^^ -- There are only 4 carbon dioxide gas molecules per 10,000 air molecules, far too sparse to trap heat photons.  The photons zip right by, hitting oxygen and nitrogen molecules, which are poor absorbers.
^^ -- Clouds are capable of blocking solar radiation, which has wavelength about 1,000,000 times shorter than heat radiation wavelength.  Clouds can block heat radiation very easily.  
^^ -- The wavelength of solar HEAT radiation is about 0.5 micron.  For Earth heat radiation, the wavelength is 15 microns.  The separation between molecules of the blocking/absorbing substance can't be far more than the wavelength of the incident radiation.  By looking at these two numbers, glass molecules surely must be considerably more than 0.5 microns apart, but considerably less than 15 microns apart.  Now, go back to "4 carbon dioxide molecules per 10,000 air molecules."  You can see that carbon dioxide molecules in the atmosphere are orders of magnitude too far apart to affect heat radiation.

text:
Ex Service technician in the heating industry speaking. Local 463 New York. Retired.
I ran emissions tests in and around NYC on large multi-boiler installations down to residential applications.
Co2 output from combustion has increased steadily. The calculator for efficiency is stack(exhaust) temperature and % of carbon dioxide in the flue gasses. High efficiency heating equipment produces, and is a adjusted for the highest practical C02(up to 15%) and lowest practical stack temperature(300f net). Pre- 1973 - 8% C02 & 500f were acceptable. 12% and 300f is the oil fired standard 15.25% is Laboratory maximum for oil fired equipment. Gas is lower. In all applications Carbon Monoxide is also a concern, and it also relates to quality of combustion and C02 levels in the exhaust gasses.
Carbon sequestration is a positive step in the right direction for any type of carbon based combustion technology.
Graduate; Iron Fireman School of Combustion, Virginia, USA. I believe in Climate Change due to man made causes.

text: I believe people underestimates the work required to convert the US from fossil to green energy.  It is not only a conversion in the power sources but a lot of work needs to go into the grid to handle all the new renewable resources.  Renewable energy sources tend to be much smaller than fossil power plants.  They also tend to turn on and off more often.  Sunlight and wind is not always consistent.  Wind doesn't always blow and clouds can reduce solar output.  This makes a lot of noise on the grid which makes it difficult to keep stable.  Large powerplants act as a filter to this noise.  Any technoldogy that gives us time to advance our grid to handle green energy is greatly needed.

text: It is basically a giant gamble: how fast the economically backed science community can solve the problems created by the economic system. It's July 2021 and we have hardly begun taking it seriously. Globally, Governments have essentially committed to 4 to 9 more years of "status quo"  --> Greenhouse gases will continue to be added to the system. We just peaked at 420ppm CO2 in May. By 2025, we are assured of hitting 430. Perhaps by then, governments will finally take it seriously. The issue is: how much damage will have been done to the Arctic by 2025? Many are forecasting our first Blue Ocean Event to occur by then. By what year will the Earth be "Carbon Neutral" ? Does anyone believe this will happen by 2035? And how do world governments both work on actively reducing emissions to zero AND support a growing worldwide population that wants more and more products and services? We have built our world upon a wholly destructive economic system and I almost NEVER come across articles about the need to move beyond it. I believe our economic system will begin to fail in the coming years as governments realize that endless consumption must stop. Social unrest will follow. Meanwhile, the Earth will continue to warm. It is widely believed that we have already committed ourselves to a 1.5 degrees Celcius increase. Many believe 2 degrees inevitable.

text: Interesting video, but a little misleading. Your video shows smoke stakes emitting a white gas, which is probably water vapor. Also, CO2 is an essential part of the atmosphere. Plants require about 150 ppm to exist and are happiest with around 1000 ppm of CO2. So, what is a good level of CO2? If CO2 is heavier than O2 (3.8 times) and O2 has trouble getting high in at atmosphere, just visit Denver, then how does CO2 get to an altitude where it causes problems (airplanes, and thermals)? So which is the worse pollutant? I've read that it is not CO2 but that it is water vapor.  Why aren't we looking at that? I am not denning climate change, but I think it is much more complex than just blaming CO2.  To make matters more complex, if you look at the NOAA temperature data for the last million years ,you will see that the earth goes through rapid temperature swings every 100,000 years or so.  We are at or near the peak of one of those swings. So some time in the future we will be on the down slope of those temperature swings. What then, as we head into global cooling?

text: What about all the christmas trees that are cut down and discarded every year? They could be used to make OSB, a building material similar to plywood, which would tie up the carbon for as long as the buildings that use it last. Then when the building is demolished, the rubble could be bricked and buried. Actually, the wood currently used to make OSB comes from fast-growing trees on tree farms - a more efficient method of CO2 capture than just planting trees, since mature forests reach an equilibrium between photosynthesis and respiration and natural decay which produce CO2. Then there are algae, which can be grown using sewage, water and atmospheric CO2, and multiply rapidly. They need little light, so they can be farmed vertically. They can be skimmed off and processed into biofuel, or just burned, which would at least be carbon-neutral. The same goes for waste biomass, like sawdust and waste wood produced by sawmills, which could be burned and used to power the mills. Garbage could also be incinerated cleanly at high temperatures, with catalytic converters sequestrating toxic combustion products, solving the problems with landfills and non-biodegradable plastics. The CO2 from burning biomass can be used to feed algae; there is even some species that produces hydrogen. As to the argument that it's an excuse for fossil fuel companies to keep pumping: they will keep pumping as long as there is demand, and we can use all the tools we can find. An unheralded contribution to reducing CO2 is the steady improvement in the efficiency of ICE engines, offset by the popularity of trucks and SUVs. EVs are all very well for the automobile industry, but there is no viable alternative as yet to fossil fuels for ships and aviation. More efficient engines and slower speeds help. There is some experimentation using sails to supplement engine power for ships. Maybe dirigibles could make a comeback? They could feasibly be powered electrically. He is a limited resource, but maybe H2 can be used for flotation, with effective fire-suppressant technology to prevent another Hindenburg disaster. One more hidden unheralded contribution to CO2 reduction is the internet, which cuts down on the amount of travelling people have to do. Average miles travelled have been steadily decreasing for a while, and covid has created a major shift from brick-and-mortar stores and workplaces. Progress is being made on many fronts, and every little bit helps.

text:
Erm...you lost me at "this is a technology we need to take seriously."  (For a channel called "undecided," you seem pretty decided.)

True, we simply must stop polluting our environment with industrialised efficiency.  The debris with which we have littered our planet is simply awesome, because lots of people have been doing it for lots of time.  (Heck, archaeology wouldn't know half of what it does about long-lost cultures if they didn't throw things away.)   The loss of the Aral Sea wasn't to "climate change," it was politics and agriculture and mismanagement.  Most of the western United States used to be under water, which is why you can find massive fields of seashells in Utah, a thousand miles from ocean.  Shall we grieve over lost species of mollusk or trilobite?  
No.

Things Change.

The "climate" is constantly changing.  In the age of dinosaurs, you would not have recognised the continents' configuration.  There were higher levels of carbon dioxide to allow plants to grow fast enough to support the voracious plant-eaters, and higher amounts of oxygen to power the megafauna of the time.  (Jurassic Park forgot to show the dinos asphyxiating because it wouldn't make as good a film.)  Then an asteroid came in for a closer look and changed the climate.  8000 years ago, it started getting warmer, and the sea levels rose significantly.  Continent-straddling glaciers turned into valley-filling seas.  Species came and went.  Just look at the ice core data.  Change is the only constant, and even the sun's output changes over time.

How do we responsibly answer the threat of CO2 levels? First, we establish that it IS in fact a threat. Sherwood Idso's research in the '80s (https://res.cloudinary dot com/highereducation/image/upload/w_740,h_541,c_scale,f_auto,fl_lossy,q_auto/v1/TheBestSchools.org/Figure-16) suggests it is not (the photo linked shows faster tree growth with increasing levels of CO2.) Additionally, CO2 concentrations aboard US submarines (which stay submerged for six months at a time) average 4000ppm, and get as high as 8000ppm; ten to twenty times the current concentrations. Plants respond better to increased CO2. If you've never seen it, just fly over the Netherlands at night and notice the swaths of greenhouses that flood the winter sky with light. In addition to light, they keep the CO2 levels extremely high so the tulips can be bloomed in time to be cut and shipped around the world in time for the first day of spring. (You can also search "Netherlands greenhouses night" and find images.)

But the argument starts something like this: CO2 levels have increased from about 280 ppm to 390 ppm over the past 150 years or so, and the earth has warmed by about 0.8 degree Celsius during that time. (eia.doe.gov/oiaf/1605/archive/gg04rpt/pdf/tbl3.pdf)  Therefore the warming is due to CO2. But correlation is not causation. Roosters crow every morning at sunrise, but that does not mean the rooster caused the sun to rise. The sun will still rise on Monday if you decide to have the rooster for Sunday dinner.

We might also track the levels of the oceans to see if there's an effect there. NOAA data from 375 long-term trend tide stations is publicly available, and their changes have been linear. Have a look at one I happen to have in hand: NOAA 8628660, 960-065, PSMSL 399 at Portsmouth, Virginia (here's a link to the data, http://sealevel.info/MSL_graph.php?id=8638660). The net change across that station has been linear for most of a century since it started; about 3mm per year. The thickness of 24 sheets of paper in your printer.
Now look at Neah Bay, Washington (http://sealevel.info/MSL_graph.php?id=9443090) It has also moved about 150mm in 50 years, but it went down.

Or look at Port Angeles, Washington, where it has risen less than one millimeter in 40 years.
Keep clicking that blue triangle to flip through other stations; that green line in all of them is CO2. Note the sea level vector line is wholly unaffected by CO2 rise.
Remember, tides change as the earth spins under the gravitational influences of the moon and sun. In the Bay of Fundy (Canada,) the difference is 50 feet between high tide and low tide, and it has nothing to do with "global warming!"

Oops, I mean "climate change"...but they changed that hyperbole when it was not all found to be warming, meaning some places are cooling.

Al Gore started this twenty years ago; If the sea levels were rising even an inch a year, the "ground floor" (so to speak) of Venice would be underwater.  Their feet aren't even wet!  (A bigger problem is that Venice's wood pilings are rotting and sinking.)

Humans have been on the planet for...in round figures...say, six million years? Look at the ice core data for CO2 levels and compare that with temperature data, or with sea levels. We've persisted without our technological innovations for at least that long because the three have nothing whatever to do with each other. Don't take anyone's word for it, get the raw data and perform your own analysis. The GISP2 research is quite revealing; search for images of it and you can see the thermal changes that took place during the Medieval Warm Period, the Roman Warm Period - and others - for yourself.

Assume for a moment that carbon dioxide is a problem.  (Spoiler:  carbon MONOxide is a problem, and that does come from petrol cars.)  That means every breathing one of us exhales tonnes of carbon dioxide, and the plants we depend on for food and oxygen in turn depend on carbon dioxide which is not a pollutant!  And people breathing accounts for only a tiny fraction of all breathing animals' CO2 output.  Or should we consider wiping out all the other oxygen-breathers?  Any volunteers?

Got 30 minutes?  Fill your worldview with as many relevant facts as you can find.  W.K.Clifford would surely approve.

text:
The soil can store far more carbon than trees.
"Soil organic matter (SOM) anchors global terrestrial productivity and food and fiber supply. SOM retains water and soil nutrients and stores more global carbon than do plants and the atmosphere combined."  https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev-ecolsys-112414-054234

Up to 70% of carbon in cultivated soils have been released into the atmosphere due to industrial agricultural practices--especially tilling, leaving bare soil after harvesting, and using synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. Regenerative agriculture can restore carbon to the soil, increasing its fertility and water-holding capacity. Regenerative agriculture can also turn deserts into productive farm land. YouTube has lots of videos on regenerative agriculture--not just theory but working farms, actual cases of regenerating degraded lands.

text:
Just did a downvote on this one; a quick glance at the comments kinda explains why, but can be summed up in one word: context. It's not that the video is bad- it's actually quite good, as are most of yours (I say "most" as I haven't seen all of them, but have seen quite a few and am making my observation- get this- in that context.)

First, I acknowledge that you've taken on a difficult task- explaining this stuff to people in this format- and that should be applauded, and thanked- and I do. I am commenting as my way to try and help you to continue to do that.

With CCUS, I think there is at least one thing that could have been stressed more in order to provide additional context (which likely contributed to many comments). That is in understanding the role CCUS can and will play (yes, when appropriately used and funded) as one component of a broad strategy of solutions being deployed to combat climate change and the human influence on our planets' climate. You mentioned it, briefly, but it may be to your viewers' benefit to consistently illustrate the relationship between these solutions in each video as you discuss one or several solutions in detail- as you did with this video on CCUS.

I won't list all of those components, but would point you to the ICC (which I'm sure you're already aware of- but ya never know who might read this) and the near-constant (now- but maybe not when this vide was first published) news coming from both international inter-governmental and public-private organizations, many third party independent watchers as well as from many governments, themselves. (Yes, having an audit trail and mechanism is important, too- and that is also being worked on- and making progress.)  

I think the context-kicker could be done with a few graphics both at the beginning and end and could do wonders for viewers who are seeing things... in silos, but not necessarily familiar with the full novel that humanity is now writing. (That makes sense, right?)

Anyhoo... great video. I'm not sure how you could ultimately provide additional context (maybe my suggestion would work, maybe it wouldn't)- but I am enjoying one of the best closed-loop approaches to story telling and independent journalism I have experienced in a long time through The Energy Transition Show with Chris Nelder. Seriously, one episode of his is like a lesson in what OCD might look like (lol/jk). I would never expect anyone to copy his approach, but if you've ever listened to one of his podcast episodes (full length) and seen his notes and noted his use of internal references to other episodes, it's almost mindblowing (and not at all in competition to your efforts... but it does make me wonder whatever happened to webrings... lol).

Please keep up the great work- and thank you for doing it!

author: olstar18

text:
Trees are great at capturing CO2, but forests are a more complex issue.  There's always a tradeoff between a forest's CO2 capture and its CO2 emissions.  Emissions come from decaying organic matter from tree litter, dead trees,the carbon bound up in the soils, from respiration as the tree's oxidize the sugars they make from sunlight, and of course fires.  As temperatures warm and forests burn more the net balance can easily turn from net CO2 sequestration to net CO2 emissions.  Beyond the massive CO2 release of a forest fire, the burn scar exposes the soils to direct sunlight and heat accelerating the decomposition of the organic material in the soils, releasing CO2.  

In subarctic forests - which are historically some of the best carbon sequestering forests - the melting of the permafrost or early melting of the seasonal frost soils also accelerates CO2 emissions in these carbon rich soils.  

In rain-forests burning to create arable land can also quickly turn the forests into net carbon emitters.  This is happening more and more often.  Also forests go through life cycles and early and mid life are when forests are most efficient at capturing and sequestering CO2, old growth forests much less so.  

It's great to have trees in your backyard and on your street, but the heavy lifting in CO2 capture happens in large forests, and warming is reducing their effectiveness considerably.

text:
We can go a long way on energy management alone. There is a high rate of 'standby loss' in equipment that maintains a 'steady state' of readiness. The heating industry can reduce consumption for heat and hot water by about 25% by converting to 'Demand fired' technology with high transfer/low mass heat exchangers/ low temperature radiant heating/ ground effect heating/cooling/modulating firing rates/ outside weather sensors, and more.
The technology is here to half a conventional home's heating and hot water bills, and was in 2005 when I left the industry. The cost benefit ratio was high for residential equipment before energy prices soared. The technology was only applied to commercial/industrial equipment. Now it is available for residential application and even at higher C02 outputs - half as much fuel makes sense.
I made my living in the Energy Efficiency game ; )

Twisted but native Madrone is considered firewood, and sold off to make room for Fir trees. It is an un-Natural Forest. - More of a farmers field laid over mountains here. 
We supply the best construction lumber to the world.
A side effect of forestation is wildfires in an ever drying climate - Burning forests give off huge amounts of toxic materials and place them in the atmosphere. There is a huge negative attached to living in or near them when they burn, and a world negative on the pollution scale. Careful management and fire preparedness is key to living here. We are in burn country and 400,000+ acres is currently burning in this state alone(on the way to 500k acres). The smoke is being detected on the east coast and I am on the west, time zones away : ( 
The Bootleg Fire (now burning)in Klamath County (source of the Klamath river and a major water supply for California) could set a new record for the State of Oregon during an Extreme and extended period of drought, with no end in sight : ( The smoke alone will kill ya !

text:
Geologists have a concept which they call "deep time."
This means that geological time is so much greater than the lifetime of a human, or even of the human species, that outlandish analogies must be used to explain it.

I have developed a concept that I call "Deep Stupid!"
This is the kind of stupid that surpasses all ordinary human understanding.Â

text:
This is just an eyewash. CO2 in the atmosphere is cumulative. We emit around 50 billion metric tons of CO2 from fossil sources into the atmosphere every year. Reducing this number doesnÂ´t change anything, it will only make the climate catastrophe set in slightly later. the CO2 in the atmosphere we already emitted will stay there, and it will stay there for good. Trees and other plants do nothing to fix the problem, while itÂ´s true that they filter CO2 out of the air to grow, they are eventually CO2-neutral, as they will emit all the CO2 they got out of the air when growing back into the air when they die. Reducing the emitted carbon by a few million tons is like using a cocktail umbrella in a hurricane. Also capturing CO2 from the air to then sell it to soda companies to carbonate their drinks isnÂ´t removing an ounce from the atmosphere, itÂ´s just making money.

We would need technology not only able to capture all the carbon that is emitted from fossil fuels, but also reducing the carbon already in the atmosphere, and even that would not help much as CO2 actually isnÂ´t really the problem, methane is. Methane from billions of cows that would never have existed if not for our pleasure. If you want to do something for the environment, eat meat-free twice a week, by that you will have accomplished more than by exchanging your car for a bike.

text:
Â @SCComegaÂ  "Algae can be tailor grown to be used for other purposes - biodiesel, polymer production, or as a stock food for other organisms."
Yup.  I get that.
But none of those things take the CO2 out of the atmosphere for more than a few months.  It is expensive carbon recycling, not carbon sequestration.
author: mafarmerga

text: Algae only works because their corpses fall to the bottom of the ocean and don't get a chance to go back into the atmosphere. Trees go back into the atmosphere. Trees don't inhale carbon and exhale oxygen. They pull carbon from the air, use it to build support material, such as branches and leaves, and as a result, oxygen is broken from the CO2. The difference is subtle in that once the tree either dies, or dumps its leaves in autumn, all of that carbon goes back into the atmosphere from microbial activity.
author: 89qwyg9yqa34t

text: Â @mafarmergaÂ  Polymer production via algae can take CO2 out of the atmosphere for decades.  Biodiesel and stock food replaces other carbon source use.  Algae is also not an expensive thing to grow - in fact it's probably the cheapest way to pull CO2 out of the atmosphere per unit of volume you're working with, at least if we're talking about atmospheric CO2.  The above methods are generally profitable as well.
author: SCComega

text: Â @89qwyg9yqa34tÂ  While such can be said of leaves, if we're speaking of farmed trees, most of that carbon is then re-used for building materials for use by humans, or other goods that remain stable for decades - and potentially longer.
author: SCComega

text: Â @SCComegaÂ  Would have to be quite a bit longer. Global warming events are measured in spans of thousands of years. Nature used to bury carbon in the form of coal and oil. Hundreds of millions of years worth of carbon is being reintroduced relatively instantly and that's what we're competing with.
author: 89qwyg9yqa34t

text:
Â @SCComegaÂ  "Polymer production via algae can take CO2 out of the atmosphere for decades. "
Annual global carbon emissions are 35 billion metric tons.  How much polymer do you think can be made from captured CO2, and what would be the energy needed to do so?

"Biodiesel and stock food replaces other carbon source use. "
True, so this might help slow the increase in CO2 levels, but it will not decrease them in any way.

"Algae is also not an expensive thing to grow - in fact it's probably the cheapest way to pull CO2 out of the atmosphere per unit of volume you're working with, at least if we're talking about atmospheric CO2."
Do you know anything about growing algae on a commercial scale?  I do.  I am a Ph.D. phycologist.  The only idea I have heard that makes any sense is growing kelp and letting it sink to the bottom of the ocean.  But even this will not be cheap.

"The above methods are generally profitable as well."
Not unless there is a significant fee placed on CO2 emissions.  Sinking kelp to the bottom of the ocean does not make anyone any money.
author: mafarmerga

text:
Â @89qwyg9yqa34tÂ  "Algae only works because their corpses fall to the bottom of the ocean and don't get a chance to go back into the atmosphere. "
And how exactly do you propose to do this in a cost effective manner?

"They pull carbon from the air, use it to build support material, such as branches and leaves, and as a result, oxygen is broken from the CO2. "
You were doing well until the end.  The oxygen released from photosynthesis comes from splitting water molecules, not from splitting CO2.

"The difference is subtle in that once the tree either dies, or dumps its leaves in autumn, all of that carbon goes back into the atmosphere from microbial activity."
True, and you can literally "see" this by looking at the annual fluctuations in the Mauna Loa datasets as CO2 levels drop in summer and climb in fall and winter.
author: mafarmerga

text:
Â @CentriolessÂ  "New generation of trees will keep recycling them into organic carbon"
Your theory only works if there is an infinite, and significant, increase in trees every year forever.
author: mafarmerga

text:
Â @mafarmergaÂ  biofuels and biopolymers are profitable as is.  Letting it sink to the bottom obviously wouldn't be, but I thought it obvious I was speaking of processes with commercial byproducts of removing CO2 from the atmosphere. 

I also do know a reasonable amount about growing algae, as I follow a lot of industry developments.
author: SCComega

text:
Â @SCComegaÂ  " biofuels and biopolymers are profitable as is."
Nope.  Show me a single biofuel that is less expensive than a comparable fossil fuel.  The only way they approach parity is if ancient carbon is taxed at a rate greater than $40/ton.  That is why I support a carbon fee.

"I also do know a reasonable amount about growing algae, as I follow a lot of industry developments."
OK.  Then share with me the name of any company in the world that is growing algae for either biofuel or carbon sequestration that is currently profitable?
Growing algae for food stocks (and baby formula) do not count because you are simply exchanging one biological food stock for another.  There is no net change in either CO2 sequestration or release.
Without a CO2 tax, fossil fuels will always have the economic advantage over all biofuels.

author: P B

text:
Why is it when you talking about all the CO2 emissions of factories you are only showing pictures of factories emitting dihydrogen monoxide? Even some of the pictures and video have been edited (probably not by you) to tint them orange, who knew that colourless and orderless CO2 was actually orange!

Also why on earth do we need very expensive facilities (likely funded by taxpayers) to capture what all plants capture naturally? Oh and news flash they turn it into oxygen, we kind of need that. In fact plants have been shown to thrive in C02 rich environments. Seems to me the best thing we could do for "nature" is to pump more of it into the atmosphere.

CO2 has an atomic weight greater than that of oxygen (O2) and nitrogen (N2), so it naturally settles to the lowest possible point. Miners will explain it to you, in no uncertain term, what happens when you're underground and the candle you are carrying goes out, yea, death. Just dig big underground caverns, and all the CO2 will settle out "naturally". Or if you want to get more space efficient put an air compressor (yea like the one you used to inflate tires) down there. Don't need some fancy fan-dangled overprice contraption you call "new technology" to capture CO2, nature has a FANTASTIC old technology for capturing it.

Why so much urgency? Year over year, on a per capita level, we have been reducing CO2 for more than a 100 years. In raw numbers more CO2 was put pumped into the atmosphere in the late 1800's and early 1900's than is being produced today.

And so what if the earth in warming. Have you heard of the "Ice Age" at one point half of the US and Europe were buried under glaciers. The Woolly Mammoths they find in the Arctic Circle have tropical plants in their stomachs. Has anyone every stopped to think that maybe the Earth in returning to its original state, where one day we will see tropical environment on the north and south poles AGAIN. And here we sit arrogantly thinking we can do anything to prevent this very natural restoration of our planet. I think we have got too big for our own britches.

And last what happens if capturing all this CO2 ends up harming the planet???

There is no such thing as an oil cave, it's stored on porous rocks from where they're pumped.

author: Dave Delecto

text:
The only real solution is CO2-free energy generation, through solar/wind + storage, and nuclear energy.
I also think the issue becomes confusing because people keep using "Carbon" and "CO2" interchangeably. If you use captured CO2 in softdrinks -- It will just be released again with a little delay.
If you capture CO2 and store it in caves or concrete, you're just sweeping the problem under the rug. I'm not saying it's a bad idea -- just that it shouldn't count as a compensation for CO2 emissions.
If you capture CO2 and turn it into liquid/solid forms of C (for example CH4 through Sabatier Process), you need enormous amounts of energy. In that case you're using fuels as a "chemical storage", and you must use renewables for generation otherwise it's not CO2 emission-negative.

text: Â @Out of ComplianceÂ  I am no scientist but there is one thing I know. CO2 affects the ph. It has to do with H2CO3. This is carbonic acid, and what is special about it is that it is unstable. It decays into CO2 and water H2O trough this reaction H2CO3-->H2O+CO2. This reaction is the problem though because, like most reactions it goes both ways, meaning that while carbonic acid decays into CO2 and H2O, the water and the carbon dioxide also react and form carbonic acid, and the more of the water and CO2 you have, the more the scale tips toward the production of acid, which desolves in the ocean (as that is where most of the water it needs to form is), which lowers the ph. That is not data from a climate change magazine, that is chemistry.

author: Nick Steggel

text:
Using chemicals such as amines and alkaline metals to capture CO2 seems to me to be self defeating.  For example to make the CaO or CaOH (un-slaked and slaked lime) you need to calcine limestone.  Which uses a lot of energy and releases CO2.  Amines are often derived from ammonia that has to be produced using an energy demanding process called the Harbor Bosch process.  You need to look at the energy balance of chemically sequestering CO2.  To my only partially informed mind it seems like we are trying to develop the chemical equivalent of a perpetual motion machine violating the rules of thermodynamics.  Now if the CO2 is sequestered in some sort of natural salt dome or pours rock that Michu be ok.  Problem there is that carbon dioxide (CO2) plus Water (H2O) yields carbonic acid H2CO3.  Carbonic acid is a mild acid that will eat away at substrate rock (how many natural caves are formed).  

I was hoping you might have examined some of these questions (especially the energy balance of chemical sequestration) and explained how researchers are working around them but, alas neither you nor anyone discussing this issue has explained how these problems have been solved.  Though perhaps not very obvious to an average viewer anyone who has ever taken a few classes in chemistry probably has the same questions so I know the scientists and engineers working on this must have a reasonable explanation or itâ€™s simply a fraud.

author: AJ GM

text: I am currently working on a Cryogenic Carbon Capture solution for heavy fuel oil powered marine vessels. Process uses a series of heat exchangers to initially cool flue gas then compress and later expand the mixture to reach -100C or below. Interesting thermodynamic property of CO2/N2 mixtures is that the CO2 will deposit (gas -> solid) out and your separation is complete. I am wondering why this topic has not been discussed, especially against amine based solutions which are very energy intensive, have a slower refresh rate (have to wait for binding and unbinding) and require cleaning to maintain.  Thoughts?

text:
No one believes in climate change more than me.  #AlGore and #BillNye are climate change deniers compare to me. 
However Anthropogenic global warming is a hoax. 
Anthropogenic climate change is complete nonsense. 

Carbon dioxide is trace levels in your atmosphere at 400 ppm. 
Furthermore, it only holds heat for a few seconds. Therefore CO2 is not the thermostat that controls our climate on this planet. Carbon dioxide is completely ineffective at driving Climate. 

History even records climate change... we all have seen climate change from 
the three major Ice-ages recorded in history to the subsequent warming 
periods (which were the Medieval warming period in the Roman warming period). 

However, Anthropogenic global warming is a complete hoax. CO2 
has nothing to do with creating global warming. CO2 Is currently 400 ppm. 
That is one carbon-dioxide molecule for every 2500 parts of the atmosphere. 
Humans contribute only a scant 16 ppm which is 4% of the total CO2 produced in a year. 

CO2 only holds heat for a few seconds and there is not enough to drive climate- it is thermodynamically impossible and yet we are told it is true. Lastly, CO2will increase only after temperatures rise and conversely CO2 levels drop as temperatures cool. In other words, CO2 levels are influenced by heat or the lack there of and therefore does not drive climate but follow climate.  #CLIMATECHANGE

text:
What I've read is, Water vapor and greenhouse gases, absorb IR photons sending most of them back into space cooling the earth by reducing the sun's heat that is able to make it to the earth's surface. 

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/features/EnergyBalance/page6.php 

"Just as the major atmospheric gases (oxygen and nitrogen) are transparent to incoming sunlight, they are also transparent to outgoing thermal infrared. However, water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, and other trace gases are opaque to many wavelengths of thermal infrared energy." "When greenhouse gas molecules absorb thermal infrared energy, their temperature rises. Like coals from a fire that are warm but not glowing, greenhouse gases then radiate an increased amount of thermal infrared energy in ALL DIRECTIONS". "Because greenhouse gas molecules radiate heat in ALL DIRECTIONS, some of it spreads downward and ultimately comes back into contact with the Earthâ€™s surface, where it is absorbed. The temperature of the surface becomes warmer than it would be if it were heated only by direct solar heating. This supplemental heating of the Earthâ€™s surface by the atmosphere is the natural greenhouse effect." Up high or down low, I don't see any difference if NASA is correct. At the height of the Atmosphere, the Earth constitutes 1/3rd of the space. So the IR absorbed by the ghg, both for incoming sun heat and emitted Earth heat, will be absorbed then emitted in "all directions". 1/3rd will hit the Earth below and the other 2/3rds will go into space. Of the Earth emitted heat, 1/3rd of that will be absorbed by the ghgs going out, and sent back to the earth adding additional warming to the earth, this warming is the greenhouse effect according to NASA. So, water vapor and the ghgs, cool the earth by blocking out 66.4% of Sun heat, while keeping in only 11% (1/3rd of 1/3rd). The atmosphere keeps out six times more heat than it keeps in. If we add more molecules of CO2 they will absorb more entering sun heat and cool the earth more than they do now. With the earth getting less heat, there will be less heat to keep in, so the GHE should fall. I don't see how, if NASA is correct, we can be warming the planet by adding more CO2 to the atmosphere.

text:
I actually clicked on this thinking it would be about the processes being tried in Asia which amount physically to being large 'vertical' gardens set up in old sky scrapers and on mountain sides. This report is old tech. Like so many science media channels now these folks like to tell us what cant be done, or show the results of past failures in an effort to stem problem solving thinking. What is the message there?  in that way its almost anti-science.

When we talk about climate change now we should say thats its origins are in the anti-population movements of the 60s. Ecology, Conservation orgs, climatology, hydrology - 'new' science disciplines or sub-disciplines created sciences that didnt study the earth, but our effect on it. So obviously their considered consensus was humans are the problem. Depopulation, was the answer, and has been baked into a lot of physical science ever since. The problem is not our tech, its us, even so in addition to being anti-homo sapien sapien, theyve become anti technology. The tone of this report was 'its foolish to expend more energy to off-set the expense of energy',  (pollution). Even in this climate "crisis"? Even if were all going to die?
What message is that to people? 

These carbon capture solutions failed, but the the need is there. Id love to see some folks in this production just lobby some ideas, silly or not, than add to the thick mat of anti- human opinion and conjecture that is smothering natural science and any research, even thought, about science based solutions to problems we've created.

In the 50s when the anti- human movement started most 3rd world countries were rural people with big families 7+ kids. Since the 90s, even in poorer countries, family size is down to 2 kids per, in 90% of the world. We already know population will level at 11B, so thats our ceiling, around when millemials die off population growth will halt and start receding as there will be less of us having kids too, certain countries in africa will be the only growth - see anything by Hans Roesling.

I got carried away here sorry. But this seemed like almost an impediment to creative thinking, old info, dead tech  - 'someone tried, it didnt work', presented as upbeat, formatted for the news, science. 
And what about those CO2 gardens in Asia?

text:
Ok, so we burn fossil fuel  producing energy, water vapor and CO2, but CO2 is bad, unless your a tree or some other flora. So we're in the process of switching our infrastructure to use renewable energy sources, which individually and collectively cannot replace hydro carbon fuels.  Neither as a full time base load source, nor can they match the energy density of hydrocarbons. So vast tracts of land or, increasingly, ocean must be allocated to harvest this resource. Once produced the energy must be stored. Lithium batteries are the current technology. Lithium is a mined product. Drawn from the ground in areas reminisent, to an older person,  of the hugh open pit coal strip mines of a few decades ago. Monstrous scars upon the earth.  Since Lithium comes from natural processes similar to the ones that produce hydrocarbons, how long before Lithium becomes scarce? Then what, graphene? Back to carbon again. How much carbon has to be manufactured to produce useable amounts of graphene? What will we do with the rejected carbon? 
One (almost) final thought, all of this to rid ourselves of CO2. Using electric motors on the same scale as the internal combustion engine will produce gargantuan amounts of Ozone. A molecule that can oxidise (corrode) almost everything. AND. . . Wait for it . . . Is a greenhouse gas!
Actual final thought, current CO2 levels globally, are above 400 parts per million (ppm).
Ozone starts becoming deadly in concentrations smaller than 10 ppm.

text:
You science-hating alarmists are going to get us all killed.  Why has every climate prediction been wrong?  Because the model (hypothesis) is wrong.  CO2 greens the planet.  Lush green forests and deserts are slightly less cold at night.  The "planet" hasn't warmed, rather the land is slightly greener.  Is greening a runaway temperature increase or stable verdant lushness?  CO2's grown 30% more plant-life than the 1930's, what happens if climatologists suddenly suck that 30% extra CO2 out of the atmosphere?  Have you "brilliant" boaster's thought it through? 

Just because CO2 drops precipitously, doesn't mean plant-life stops breathing-in CO2.  So when 130% plant-life attempts to breathe-in 66% of previously available CO2, "brilliant" climate alarmists just created a disaster.  A plant-life disaster.  All plants will suffer.  Most will die.  

Remember the movie, "Idiocracy?"  Climatologists are like those leading the world in that movie and removing CO2 from the atmosphere will have similar results. 

So when "brilliant" boasting alarmists create dust-bowls and famine and they try to blame it on climate-change, remember this scientist warned you what was about to happen.  This scientist made the only accurate prediction (based on a different, accurate model).  And when this scientist is proven correct, don't go running to the braggarts who got you in trouble in the first-place, because they'll only make things worse.

author: Platz Halter

text:
Â @HeronidenÂ  no no. You misunderstand me.
The point of carbon capture is to store it in one or another way.
The paper for the production of concrete has one major flaw in the way it is presented here.
You need substances that can react with the CO2 to bind it. In the classic way Limestone is used as a binder for the sand and rock. But Limestone is CaCO3. You burn it to get CaO. This reacts with water to Ca(OH)2. And this reacts with CO2 to CaCO3 and water. This is one part why concrete works. This process is responsible for 8-10 % of the worlds CO2 emissions. So its well known, basic and not easy to replace.

What was mentioned in the paper was the possebility to use slag from the Iron production as a costruction Material. The point here is, that the thing that reacts with the CO2 is unused CaO that is left in the slag. You put Limestone in the blast furnace to get rid of the unwanted silicates, but in this process CO2 is already emitted. So the only thing you do is to use the not correct calculated excess amount of burned Limestone. This is pure greenwashing. Because the slag is already used as building material and is using the CO2 from the air.
So the little bit of extra CO2 that binds in the material is nothing to the extra amount of energy you use to capture the CO2 and transport it. 

The other discripted method of using minerals of the serpentine group is nothing new, but it works. So these are minerals that can bind the CO2 for a Long Time. This is also needed for the CCS sites that want to mineralize the CO2. If its done with renewable energy, you can call it the best way to remove CO2 out of the atmosphere.

I hope this explained the point better than before.
author: Platz Halter

text:
â€‹Â @Abram CarrollÂ  Soil-bound carbon is not really a plant nutrient. Soil bound nitrogen is. "We" didn't really do anything novel with nitrogen fertilizers; soil bound nitrogen is already how most plants get their nitrogen. We just introduced refinement process and methods for getting nitrogen salts that fell out of the nitrogen cycle and into mineral deposits back up to the surface where plants could get them. Nitrogen fertilizers generally do not involve capturing atmospheric nitrogen to make them.

Also, highly refined nitrogen fertilizers are a massive ecological problem.

Turning all your accounts into 'high efficiency' uses less fuel and reduces profits for the fuel $upplier$, and also increases maintenance costs for your Service Department . it equals a lose/lose for Gas & Oil sales over years - for doing the right thing and reducing consumption. Heating equipment that is sixty plus years old is still in service today, and it drinks fuel like a drunk on a Saturday night ! The 'incentive' is to keep it running and sell more fuel, unless the account is in jeopardy of leaving. That keeps an Energy supplier healthy at the customer's expense.
Trees can help, but they can't get it done. Wildfires turn them into pollution : (

text:
Â @Abram CarrollÂ  In the right hands. Money greases the wheels of the Carbon sales industry. The more you use - the more you are worth to Exon-Mobil/Shell/ Texaco - your Utility - and every other 'supplier'. Their cash incentive is NOT to reduce your consumption but to increase it. They want to sell you fuel but have to sell you efficiency to keep your business. That is the only reason energy providers promote high efficiency equipment.
 It goes against their long term financial interests. They don't WANT to do it in the first place ! Their income goes down and service costs for the equipment go up. In the end fuel sales dwindle to half, and repair costs skyrocket, while reliability goes down. They Lose big time !

author: Griz erbear

text:
Â @Platz HalterÂ  You're talking about ancient concrete but there's a reason we don't make it that way anymore.  The current aggregate is just so much better.

I guess I'm not saying it can't be used as a building supply- just that it's impractical.  Carbon requires some sort of processing to be useful in construction.  Like made into fibers and infused with resin to make carbon fiber.  By itself it's soft.  So if you're trying to process essentially carbon fiber beams for in a house you're going to have a super lightweight house... with a really really heavy cost. 

There could come a process which streamlines the production of carbon composites and makes it really cheap but as someone who keeps their finger on the pulse of emerging tech, I've not heard of anything on the horizon.
author: Polydynamix

text:
Â @#YOUdon'thavetoreadthispost.Â  I suppose that depends on the balance.  If it costs 2 to save 4 then it's a wise investment, though any environmental benefits would take twice as long. 

We see it happen all the time though with recycling.  Only a few materials are actually worth recycling.  Aluminum for example.  Things like paper though, require gross bleaching processes that produce toxic waste that is arguably worse than the mostly safe compost that paper could be made into. Plastic is rarely even recycled even when you recycle it- it usually gets picked apart for a few specific types of plastic and the rest ends up in a landfill anyway.

text:
A rant.
  Someone please explain to me that 10T tonnes is not the equivalent of a cuboid of water measuring 1000 X 10 X 1 Km. If I'm wrong then I'm wrong. I might be wrong but I'm not. Please think about that volume and mass of liquid and tell me that it is a perfectly reasonable idea to pump it underground or turn it into walls. Are there really that many walls on Earth? Is there an engineer out there who can tell me how big the bath plug needs to be to drain the 1000 X 10 X 1 Km bath in lets say 5 years?  Of course the bath will have to be under a pressure of about 10 bar and so will the place you drain into. I recognise that liquid CO2 would be denser than water, approx = e,  so maybe the bath would ONLY be 400 X 10 X 1 Km.
  I think that we should calculate the mass of the atmosphere which is really easy to do. 5.15 by 10 to the 15 tonnes, so 10T tonnes would be ONLY  about 0.2% of the atmosphere. There is a bit of a snag here, CO2 levels are at 0.04% of the atmosphere!  So we'll have 50T tonnes of anti-CO2 in the atmosphere and all life will be extinct, relying as it does on CO2. I need help form a physicist here 'does anti-CO2 exist?'. Can anti-plants use anti-CO2 to feed anti-humans (otherwise known as feminists)?
  The fundamental question is 'Is CO2 bad?' If yes 'how?' and prove it. If not then what are we doing debating putting 0.2% of the atmosphere underground and destroying all life on Earth (as if we had that power).

text: These are a paradox, you need power to run these capture plants, most power is generated by burning fossil fuels, so your burning carbon to capture carbon. But go on greenies, harp on about getting off fossil fuels entirely and only using renewables... That is a pipe dream and nothing more, ALL renewables have inherent limiting factors, many requiring standby power systems run by.... FOSSIL FUELS. And lets not forget you need fossil fuels to make renewable systems, and these carbon capture plants, and that is an inescapable fact, as steels and solar panel glass requires coal to be burnt so that product can absorb some of its properties to give the strength required. So Co2 capture simply captures the Co2 required to build and run them.

text: The big problem with carbon capture that I see is that it feels like just a fundamental thermodynamic impossibility. author: Aaron'sShed

text:
Trying to store CO2 into structures using CO2 extracting machines and absorbing it chemically into concrete is ridiculous when you have a much easier and cost effective way to accomplish the same: wood!

Modern wood building techniques are advanced and allow for very safe multi story buildings. It builds fast and it stores CO2 for a very long time. And wooden buildings are actually a safer alternative to concrete when it comes to fire hazards too. Ask any firefighter. Because wood does indeed burn but thick wood doesn't catch fire easily and when it does burns predictably. Whereas concrete becomes unreliable quickly when the temperature rises and can even explode and crumble as the steel reinforcement inside expands under heat.

Wood building is slightly more expensive still but when companies start to have to pay for CO2 emissions and can even trade CO2 absorption on the market then wood building will quickly become a very profitable business.

High tech wood structures are the best manmade longterm CO2 storage options available today.

text: I think one of the most important discussion topics on this subject is that direct air capture targets ALL CO2 in the atmosphere.  According to the IPCC, humans are responsible for less than 4% of all carbon released into the atmosphere.  This means that regulations designed to limit carbon emissions affect a very small portion of the problem (theoretical maximum of 4% of CO2 emissions).  Whereas direct air capture attacks all 100% of carbon in the atmosphere.  Direct air capture would allow humans to be carbon negative instead of just carbon neutral.

author: ewan derric

text:
The truth about "carbon capture" and its cousin "clean coal" is they are political technologies. They were devised as propaganda to paint dirty technologies as fixable. These  technologies can never ever come close to handling a tiny fraction of the carbon we emit. While we can demonstrate the technology, we could never scale it up to any meaningful benefit.

Back in the early 1980s Ohio had a vote on whether to ban no-deposit drink containers. The beverage industry went into shock fearing if it passes in a state like Ohio it will go nationwide (since it hasn't gone nationwide they were probably right). So the beverage industry poured tons of money into political advertising to defeat the proposal. But it wasn't enough to be against, they needed an alternative to tout so they came up with the "Practical Litter Law" and blanketed the airwaves promoting it. The way the fantastic "Practical Litter Law" was supposed to work was the state would hire work crews and they would go pick up all the discarded containers creating JOBS, JOBS, JOBS! The ban failed at the ballot box and the "Practical Litter Law" evaporated to the point if you google it today you don't get any results. "Carbon capture" is the 21st century version of the "Practical Litter Law", but even more impractical.

text:
Just a comment from someone working in the industry: The only mature technology (TRL9) for CO2 capture at low concentration is amine. To remove CO2 from amine, you need additional 3GJ/t of CO2. It means you spend much more energy than needed to capture CO2, and then more pollution, more money... Many companies are really waiting for a better technology. 

In Europe, you have a CO2 pricing policy. Morgan Stanley expects a 90â‚¬/tCO2 by 2030. The amount of CO2 industries are producing is +100(0) times bigger than the current CO2 markets you told us about.
It means than both releasing CO2 into the air or capture it without using it (storage) might make the industries go bankrupt. If the economy is going down, much less people is interested in environment...

The biggest efforts to be made are in creating a sustainable market using CO2 and finding a new CO2 capture with high energy efficiency.
We are far from it...

text:
You say -- without stating any evidence whatsoever -- that this is just an excuse for the major oil refiners to keep on "polluting." 

Btw , C02 is not pollution; it's a gas that's normally present in the atmosphere. Cigarette smoke is pollution. Burning wood produces pollution. Burning any fossil fuel produces pollution, but C02 is not one of the pollutants. 

Do you have anything like quotes from the CEOs of Shell or Exxon that this is indeed what they are interested in doing ... buying time so they can keep on polluting? 

You also just take it for granted that we can start out with a good program right now for reducing carbon emissions and ramp it up for a few decades and viola ... problem solved. This is naive beyond belief. From a scientific standpoint, that MIGHT be possible and might keep us below the level of catastrophe. But it totally ignores the political and economic obstacles facing such a program. For one, China and India are not going to go along with this. They are rapidly modernizing are not going to stop. They are going to be using more, not less, fossil fuels in the future. Also, tampering with the world economy which right now is solidly based on the consumption of fossil fuels, could easily lead to a worldwide depression and even the deaths of millions and the impoverishment of billions.
