Climate change is man made and is a big problem even if the media and some percentage of politicians make it out to be worse or better than it actually is. Humanity will NOT go extinct from climate change we will reduce emissions enough before that ever has a snowball's chance in hell of happening; but the world we live in and more realistically the following generations will be worse than if we change now.

text:
Â @NocareÂ  Just popping in with the obligatory "solar isn't that good" comment.

It's a start, and a move in the right direction, but comparatively, solar is rather primitive honestly. Solar panels suffer from a bizarre phenomenon where their efficiency vastly decreases within weeks, months, maybe a year or two, of their creation. They're also only set to operate for around 25 years, although newer iterations may last longer, after which they require disposal or recycling. Unless properly recycled, solar panels become environmentally toxic waste. Solar farms also take up a considerable amount of land and only really operate during the day. Until more effective storage methods are either finally invented or finally allowed, depending, that's going to be quite an issue.

In summary, there is a LOT more that needs to be done for solar to actually be an industrial-grade option. We should be doing that now, but the better option probably still lies in modular nuclear reactors, or if they can create those fusion reactors and get more output than input.

text:
You mentioned the right answer in you opening, and then you prattled on with the scam, Matt.  CCUS has only been used for Enhanced Oil Recovery, literally.  
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_capture_and_storage#Industrial-scale_projects  
Read the laundry list of EOR as the endgame for CCS and understand it was never a carbon negative strategy and always an excuse to continue burning fossils.  Neoliberals used to call it "Clean coal"

It's all handwaving.  You also made a tragically bad argument in your opening.  You said, "But renewables alone, aren't enough to lower emissions at the rate that is needed."  Wrong.  Take the wasted R&D money and much higher cost of fossils that would go to perpetuating their use with the proven-to-be-useless CCUS strategy, and instead invest that money in actual renewable creation.  Continuing to pretend that CCUS is an actual net-zero carbon strategy for 20 more years will easily cost us more in Climate Crisis related damages and adaptation than it costs to invest heavily in retiring all of the fossil plants.  Our problem is the will to act with the power and speed of a motivated government backed by a motivated society.  We are acting like spoiled children, afraid to interrupt GDP growth with an actual quick government-led strategy.  We have the money, but we've put our commitment to capitalism and the free market over the future of our planet.  

"The NRG representative also confirmed that the coal unit is continuing to operate without capturing its emissions. So carbon emissions from the power plant have increased â€“ although only slightly, since the project captured just 7% of the power plantâ€™s emissions when it was operating."
"https://www.energyandpolicy.org/petra-nova/
Petra-nova is the General Motors, the IBM, GE of the CCS world.  They have shown you that it's not a real strategy.

CCS is being used LESS and LESS.  As an extreme technophile, Matt, you buy into this BS that it's a growing industry or that it will ever make any sense.  DAC has the same problem of being too energy/materials intensive to be energy or financially viable.  It's only being talked about because those who want Business As Usual are paying policy makers to write it into their strategies.  It's sad that people who understand science, can't stop being distracted by future tech while we're in a Climate Emergency.  With existing solar, wind, geothermal, and pumped hydro storage technology, we could solve electric production problem TODAY and in the very short term.  It's only will and distraction of future tech and our free-market economy led approach that is killing our progress.

author: Martin Charles Pitt-Bradley

text:
Rick is absolutely right.  I don't know much about the details of carbon capture technology, but I am familiar with the second law of thermodynamics, which tells me in no uncertain terms that it will take more energy to recapture the CO2 in stable form than we ever got from burning that carbon in the first place.  Anyone who understands this is not the least bit surprised that carbon capture technology is not being implemented in our smokestacks, because if fossil-fuel-based power plants tried to sequester any meaningful percentage of the carbon they burned, they would defeat their own purpose by becoming net-importers of energy.  For similar reasons, the attitude of "let's burn it now, capture it later" is absolute insanity.  LEAVING IT IN THE GROUND is the only sensible policy.  Yes, we should invest in the research and development of carbon capture technology, but it won't make sense to implement large-scale sequestration efforts until our energy supply comes from non-fossil-fuel sources.

In the long term, sustainable energy is not the moral path forward, but rather it is tautologically, by definition, the ONLY path forward.  It's time we recognize that for every ton of carbon-based fossil fuel we dig up, we are living on borrowed energy, and increasingly, on borrowed time.

author: Martin Charles Pitt-Bradley

text: Â @Martin Charles Pitt-BradleyÂ  That's a good point.  I was careful not to speak out against all carbon-based fuels.  In principal it is possible for them to be created sustainably.  Biofuels are another example of a carbon-based fuel that can be carbon neutral when done right.  But I think we're both on the same page that fossil fuels need to stay right where there are, in the ground, because they are already maximally sequestered.  It takes energy to pull them out of the earth, and it would take even more energy recapture that carbon once it's burned and try to put it back.  This is the important point that I think a lot of people miss when they think of carbon capture as a quick fix that will allow us to keep doing what we're doing with fossil fuels.

author: Ralph Ellis

text:
There is no empirical evidence that increasing CO2 causes increasing global warming.
(Correlation does not imply causation).   

An increasing greenhouse effect depends upon increased re-radiation from CO2 in the atmosphere, and this manifests itself as a tropical tropospheric hotspot plus increased Downwelling Longwave Radiation (DLR) which warms the surface.   However, this hostspot and increasing DLR have never been detected.  In which case, CO2 cannot be causing global warming.

And we know that CO2 is not causal, because during the ice ages - when CO2 levels were high the world cooled, and when CO2 levels were low the world warmed.  The climate would not do that, if CO2 was the primary feedback agent.  

In reality, the primary feedback agent is ice-sheet albedo (reflectivity), which is modulated by dust.  Yes, the data shows that temperature is inversely proportional to dust.  So it is dust-albedo that modulates ice ages, and  this explains all the manifold aspects of the ice age temperature cycle.  Please see my latest science paper on ice ages, which demonstrates that CO2 was NOT controlling world temperature at that time.  

Modulation of Ice Ages via Dust and Albedo:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987116300305 

Ralph.

What exactly is the big deal with burning coal and gas and whatever they use to generate electricity, when the exhaust is just O2 with perhaps 1000 ppm CO2?

text:
"Climate Change," aka "Global Warming" is not scientific fact BASED ON THE PARAMETERS THAT CLIMATE SCIENTISTS THEMSELVES HAVE PROVIDED. Let me say that again,  based on the own measurement parameters that Climate Scientists have put forth, we have NO hard-scientific proof that global warming is occurring.  The entire  increase in aggregate global temperatures claimed by "climate experts," is 0.7 degrees C.  But here is the key, THE MARGIN OF ERROR OF ALL OF THE TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS IS 1.0 DEGREES C!  Again, this is the claim that climate scientists are making. So based on hard scientific fact, we don't even know if the aggregate temperature of the earth is increasing.  

There are something like 7-8 different temperature measurement systems employed by several major agencies that are used to measure the aggregate temperature of the earth. ALL of these different measurement systems introduce a different marginal degree of error  into the total temperature calculations. So it is a safe bet that the actual margin of error of the AGGREGATE  earth's temperature is greater than the 1.0 degrees C that is being claimed by climate scientists! 

The liberal media and groups (read the Democratic Party) pushing the global warming hoax have political goals, driven by the huge amounts of money involved. Al Gore, the high priest of the religion of global warming is now worth over $200 MILLION dollars. His global warming charade has made him fabulously rich.  The amount of money that governments are pushing into this farce is staggering.  The down payment for the Paris Accord that the United States would have had to pay is $4 BILLION  DOLLARS. Under the Accord's clauses, this would rise to over 10 BILLION DOLLARS in less than 10 years. But wait, that's not all, the amount that American taxpayers would be on the hook for under the Paris Accord WOULD HAVE CONTINUED TO INCREASE.  Fortunately, President Trump was intelligent enough to withdraw from this insane agreement. Further, US taxpayers would have been paying the highest amount of costs for this  "climate accord" of any country and we have one of the best non-polluting records for large industrial countries, so these astronomical costs were not merited, even IF global warming was occurring. 

BTW,  the Paris Climate TREATY is the correct name for what we call the Paris Accord. The reason it was called an "accord" in America is because Obama, an extreme leftist, FORCED THE USA INT0 THIS AGREEMENT. Obama KNEW that the "treaty" would not be ratified in congress and so he unilaterally forced America into a bastardized "accord." 

But let's directly address Ferrell's claim of increased CO2 emissions: 

1. By all accounts C02 emissions have gone up in the last 30 years, but it is VERY questionable whether or not that this is anthroprgenic (caused by man).  There is NO solid proof of that because the earth emits tremendous amounts of C02 naturally.

2. The actual percentage of C02 in the atmosphere is debatable but some have measured it at less than 1% and others up to 0.04%. Think about this critically for a minute. That means of ALL the gases in the atmosphere, the TOTAL amount of C02 os 0.00004.  95% of ALL C02 emissions are natural. So the percentage of that 0.04% is (0.04 x .05) = 0.002% of man made emissions.Think about that number, it is in the hundreds of a percent and yet supposedly intelligent people are saying that it is radically changing our planet's temperature. There are several different explanations online from climate change promulgators, but the their arguments defy commonsense as well as hard science.

3. Add to this the FACT that C02 is just ONE of dozens of greenhouse gases and you quickly begin to realize that even if global warming was real, and it isn't, reducing JUST C02 emissions would have little affect on global temperatures.

text:
Graphene is an allotrope of carbon consisting of a single layer of atoms arranged in two-dimensional honeycomb lattice. The name is a portmanteau of "graphite" and the suffix -ene, reflecting the fact that the graphite allotrope of carbon consists of stacked graphene layers.
GrapheneÂ is 200 timesÂ strongerÂ than steel by weight. It is 1,000 times lighter than paper. It is 98 percent transparent. It conducts electricity better than any other known material at room temperature. It can convert light at any wavelength into a current.

text:
Carbon capture would use the energy of 5 units of Fossil Fuel for every unit of Fossil Fuel burned.  Looking carefully at direct air capture in particular assumes the energy comes from excess renewable les that are above the immediate demand due to supply peaks.  The cost of these carbon capture plants will be immense and dwarfed by simply not using Fossil Fuel in the first place.   

While most say trees are the answer this is mistaken since if we were to plant every square foot of arable land with trees in one year it would still not equal the amount of carbon emissions produced in that year. Essentially, even if we gave up growing food, trees would not suck up enough carbon dioxide to slow down the increase in an appreciable fashion. I recall it around 90% of the carbon dioxide is absorbed by the ocean anyway which gives us a false idea as to how much carbon dioxide actually has to be removed since the ocean is acting as a carbon sink and we need another one.

others have stated that the carbon dioxide should be pumped into greenhouses to make plants grow which is not necessarily true for many plants that have evolved with the existing level of carbon dioxide. For those planes that would thrive in higher concentrations, there are complications such as the requirement for more water and other minerals so itâ€™s not just an easy fix.

I mentioned Direct Air carbon capture which is probably the most expensive process but capturing carbon from coal fired plants would make them even less competitive than they are now since in most cases they already cost more than renewable energy. It would be far better to use that investment to create more renewable energy which would give immediate and long lasting results and not encourage the use of coal which has problems beyond its carbon production such as the toxic byproducts.

By far the cheapest solution is to start taxing fossil fuels for firstly the healthcare costs they incur which is around $120 billion per year in the US and kills around 110,000 people in the US and around 40 million people worldwide. The fossil fuel industry gets away with pushing those costs onto the general population as it does the environmental costs which globally probably exceed the price of the fossil fuel by a factor of 10. He study at Stanford showed that the cost of burning fossil fuels was around $65 trillion in an $86 trillion world economy meaning that stopping the production and use the fossil fuels as quickly as possible would benefit virtually everybody on the planet. Fossil fuels should only be used as a transition to renewable energy.

Well some countries have place limits on the final date that fossil fuel vehicles can still be produced they are by and large much much much too far in the future to have the effect we need if we intend to drastically lower carbon dioxide in the next 10 years. Pretending that this can be done by carbon capture is a fools errand because the cost of doing so would be dramatically greater than simply switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy along with storage.

Looking at the issue from first principles makes the situation much clearer. The earth has been storing carbon in fossil fuels for several billion years so to pretend that we can release these in one century and not suffer the toxic consequences is absurd.

text:
Nuclear reactors are an excellent way to produce greenhouse gas free electricity and they could power these carbon  scrubbers.
   New advances such as small modular reactors built on an assembly line and trucked out to sites around the globe that could be as common as a Walmart or a hospital. Truly enabling a local power grid coupled with wind and solar.
   Make no mistake that there are forces that want to make nuclear power so expensive that it's not viable.
   When you look at the worst case scenarios of Chernobyl and Fukushima you can see that nuclear power is truly not the boogeyman that people want to make it out to be,  but rather the overreaction to an accident.
   I recommend podcasts such as Titans of Nuclear and lots of YouTube channels educating on how nuclear power works,  including the economics.
   I would much rather live next door to a nuclear power plant than a coal or natural gas plant.

text: sjn 72 From Climeworks homepage:â€We remove carbon dioxide from the air with our direct air capture machines. Carbfix then mixes the carbon dioxide with water and pumps it deep underground. Through natural mineralization, the carbon dioxide reacts with the basalt rock and turns into stone within a few years.â€
author: Svante Forsman

text:
Â @Svante ForsmanÂ  As I mentioned in another comment here, direct air capture is a dumb idea - it is extremely energy intensive and poorly scalable. The only solution is point of source capture, why wait for it to be diluted in the atmosphere? It sounds great to the public but it is really a dumb idea.

Yes, carbon dioxide will react with water to form carbonic acid (it is actually in equilibrium with gaseous CO2, aqueous CO2 and carbonic acid, very little of it is carbonic acid), you can neutralize the carbonic acid with minerals such as calcium and magnesium, to form carbonate minerals. This is nothing new or special. Pumping this underground takes massive amounts of energy and you can only do this where there are large deposits of compatible minerals, so then you have to ship CO2 all over the world which takes energy. Nothing is free.
author: sjn 72

text:
sjn 72 Climeworks is not shipping CO2 anywhere. It works and they are getting customers who are willing to pay for it. 
Even if we stop all emissions today we still have all the â€legacyâ€ emissions to deal with ie we have to reduce the atmospheric CO2 to levels that are safe long term, probably below 350ppm. Every ton of removal will be valuable and I think DAC will be one of several methods we will use.
author: Svante Forsman

text:
Â @Svante ForsmanÂ  I didn't say Climeworks is shipping CO2. DAC is a dumb dumb idea. Flue gas is around 25% CO2 or 250,000 ppm whereas in the air CO2 is 400 ppm. It makes no sense to capture CO2 from the air at 400 ppm when you can capture it at the source where it is at 250,000 ppm. Why wait for it to dilute?. This is really engineering 101. It takes a tremendous amount of energy to capture CO2 at 400 ppm, where does that energy come from? Burning coal?

Removing a ton of CO2 is inconsequential when 40 B tons are released annually. It's like saving a sinking ship with a teaspoon. Climeworks has only 2500 subscriber in the entire world, what they are doing has no effect on anything.
author: sjn 72

text: sjn 72 Only renewable energy is being used. They are scaling up as we speak. And so is the canadian company Carbon Engineering.
author: Svante Forsman

text: Â @Svante ForsmanÂ  Why burn coal and then use renewable energy to capture the CO2 when you could have just used the renewable energy in the first place? This makes no sense. Go look at Carbon Engineering's picture of their DAC on their website. It is tiny (the size of a shed). Now compare that to a coal fired power plant. According to their own literature, their DAC process is powered by natural gas.

This way you use global warming to grow food, make salt and materials such as hemp and bio oil to be harvested. This may be better long term than carbon sequestering.

text:
Just to comment on a single aspect of this video, capturing CO2 from air to put it into carbonated drink is not really doing anything. The person drinking the drink will not absorb the CO2, it will just go back to the atmosphere pretty quickly. 

It's a fringe problem, but many of the CCOS projects have comparable problems, where either the storage is non-permanent, or the capture requires energy that is still generated from fossile fuels, so there is no net-effect.

It's really time we start understanding that no amount of technological process available within the next 50 years will free us from the responsibility of significantly reducing our consumption, especially for those of us part of the global 1% (i.e. those having a monthly income of more than 2500$ PPP).

text:
Â @Joe DennehyÂ  I don't agree with the figures nor your statement.
At least 2 of those naturel emissions are forest fires and animal breathing. About the latter, most animals are raised for meat so that's human induced. The natural balance would have a lot less animals alive, that includes humans.
Forest fires : science tells us that forest fires are gaining in strength due to human activity, they way we manage forests and global heating. Ironically not letting forest burn naturally, monoculture and clear cutting leads to much more massive fires.
Global heating may well be a big part of a natural cycle but we're contributing to accelerating that cycle and the unbalance is exponential, it's a vicious circle. Also "real" natural CO2 emissions are balanced out naturally by natural carbon storage. The unbalance we've created cannot be handled by the natural process.
Accelerated global heating is also responsible for early release of previously naturally stored CO2 and methane, for example by the thaw of permafrost. Have a look at the effects in Siberia, Alaska and even the French Alps.
The natural process can very well sustain the "real" amount of natural CO2 emissions. 
So it seems obvious that the figures are false, and even if not by a whole lot, say maybe 90%/10% (maybe more maybe less) those figures hide the fact that it's the unbalance (and  the exponential factor) that is the problem not the pourcentages whatever they really are.

text:
Luckily, capitalism already solved the problem 100 years ago.

The minimum global forest cover percentage was in 1912. We have more trees and other photosynthesizing plants now than at any time since. 
https://psmag.com/environment/the-planet-now-has-more-trees-than-it-did-35-years-ago

Most environmental groups only talk about the total amount of trees harvested in a given year to make it seem like we're in dire straits. But of course, like Matt said, it's all about money and the eco groups need to make things look scary to get donations. 

Truth is, the reason we have so many trees today is because logging companies adopted long-term plans to increase the forest cover. Makes sense that a company that relies on trees being around would want to make sure there are plenty of trees in bio-diverse forests. 
https://www.nippon.com/en/ncommon/contents/japan-data/213859/213859.png

Thing is, they use the term "carbon capture" to evoke images of soot and smoke and smog. But it's nice, invisible carbon dioxide. And what do plants need a lot of? Carbon dioxide for photosynthesis! It's literally a greenhouse gas because it's added to greenhouses to help the plants grow better. If you look at satellite images over the last 50 years, the planet keeps getting greener because there's more CO2 for the plants. 

This is nothing more than an expensive, complicated solution to a non-problem.

text: Seems to me that there is no SERIOUS way to eliminate CO2 (net) emissions, until we can stop burning fossil fuels.  We won't stop burning fossil fuels until we have a viable substitute.  Wind and solar probably won't get there (I would like to be wrong, but I just don't see it).  Nuclear Fusion, particularly P-B11 fusion would certainly do it... If only we could make that work (and work in a cost effective manner).  There are some promising developments here, but it still looks to be 10+ years away, so this probably shouldn't be relied upon.  Today's Nuclear Light Water Reactors (LWRs) could do it, but they have costs and waste issues.  The waste issue seems to be overblown... It just isn't as bad as the hype makes it out to be.  The cost issue really comes down to regulations and "inherent" safety.  This is a complex issue, but the bottom line is that the cost of any Nuclear (Fission) Power generating system is very much driven by the INHERENT safety aspects of the reactor design.  Molten Salt Reactors (MSRs) are a newer, generation IV, type of reactor that is MUCH safer by INHERENT design.  (A simple google search on Molten Salt Reactors or MSRE will yield much info here).  If we had NRC regulations in place for MSRs that are much easier (lower cost) to comply with (because these regulations efficiently reflect the MSRs inherent safety advantages), MSRs could be constructed and operated at a much lower cost.  The 10X cost increase that has occurred over the years for LWRs could be reduced or eliminated with MSRs.  MSR look promising as a method to produce energy at a fraction of todayâ€™s costs (and a HUGE reduction in the waste produced as well).  With MSRs we can produce MUCH more energy!  The energy available in nuclear fuels (Uranium or Thorium) is a Million times that of any fossil fuel.   With energy this abundant, we can solve many of the worlds resource limitation problems!  The standard of living for all people on earth can increase many fold.  The potential advantages of MSRs are simply stunningly!  We would stop producing CO2 and putting it into the air.  We could even extract CO2 from the air in a means discussed in the video.  Or, we could simply grow trees and harvest them and store them in old coal mines... Reversing the processes of coal burning that has taken place of the past 200+ years.  Since plants actually thrive in relatively high CO2 environments, we would have to determine the optimum level of CO2 in the atmosphere.  It might actually be higher than what it was 100 or so years ago!
author: William Thesling

text:
During almost all of the 55-yr period of The Great Acceleration (google it), weed and itâ€™s non-THC cousin, HEMP, have been illegal to grow in the US. So the eco-benefits of hemp are rarely mentioned. It grows rapidly in poor soil, and so can be grown in places where it does compete with productive farmland. It is one of the densest grasses and per acre generates far more biomass than forests. 
     There are no magic bullets, but hemp can be used to pull carbon out of the air, improve the quality & productivity of farm soils, and sequester the carbon for hundreds of years. 
     Using a simple, proven process, the hemp is converted to biochar by heating in an O2-free device not anymore complicated than a meat smoker. The biochar is tilled into farmland, where it binds to soil materials. So long as the land is farmed in a sustainable way & protected from erosion, the biochar can stay safely in the soil for a very long time. 
     Itâ€™s a win-win. Farms are more productive and CO2 is pulled out of the air more quickly, due to the much more rapid growing cycle of hemp compared to trees.

text:
What happens when you capture too much carbon?  Will it send us into the next ice age?  
The only viable carbon capture plant pumped the gas into an oil well specifically so they could get MORE OIL out of the well. When the oil pice tanked they stopped capturing CO2. 
Molten salt nuclear fuelled by stored used fuel is the way forward. Zero CO2 at source. Equally important, it burns down the high level nuclear waste. The stuff with a 30,000 year half life ends up at just 30 years. In the process it extracts 24 times more power than the original PWR extracted. 
When the regulatory process allows these will be cheap enough to put coal out of business and will eat into the market for methane gas.

text: This is so stupid that it's difficult to reply to. A) The goal is, and always has been, to get to pre-industrial levels of atmospheric CO2, not to eliminate CO2 from the atmosphere. Plants were thriving LONG before humans starting burning fossil fuels, they don't rely on humans pumping CO2 into the atmosphere for survival. B) We currently monitor atmospheric levels of CO2, so we'd know if we were getting close to pre-industrial levels of atmospheric CO2 LONG before getting there. C) Getting down to pre-industrial levels of atmospheric CO2 is basically impossible without adopting an entirely new economic system, so we're not likely to significantly reduce the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere until there is a massive societal collapse of some kind.

text:
It is both a necessity, AND an excuse for the Fossil Fuel Industrial Complex to keep polluting. 
I don't know how we ultimately get to carbon output neutrality, but surely we should be pursuing an All Of The Above strategy if technically feasible. We've been pursuing an All You Can Burn strategy and knowingly terraforming a new atmosphere for decades. It is way past due for humanity to be serious about repairing the damage we have wreaked on the planet.
What does All Of The Above look like?
- Decreased Overall Energy Consumption: eg. Building Efficiency, Construction Materials. Reuse, Recycling, Telepresence, Decreased Meat Consumption, Vehicle Efficiency, Carbon Pricing
- Decarbonize Energy Production: Solar, Wind, Geothermal, Hydroelectric, Nuclear, andâ€”The Dream Solutionâ€”Fusion
- Carbon Capture and Sequestration: Reforestation/Afforestation, Emission Capture, Atmospheric Capture, Construction Material Sequestration, Soil Carbon Enrichment
- Geoengineering: Stratospheric Aerosol Injection, Marine Cloud Seeding, Space-Based Solar Mirrors (for realz)

author: Chad Tennant

text:
There is FAR more potential for carbon capture - using plants*. Our agriculture is currently *producing a LOT of GHG - artificial nitrogen fertilizer in particular is very problematic. It kills the life in the soil, that is forming the soil, and this releases carbon. And the hidden source of GHG - is that nitrogen becomes nitrous oxide - which is about 8X worse than *methane*.

Grasslands are another huge potential to sink carbon very quickly and cheaply - grassland hold more carbon per acre than forest, and there is more grassland than forest. Grass grows very quickly, and if we manage herds of herbivores - we could sink far more carbon into the soil more quickly than virtually any other way.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wgmssrVInP0

We could be back below 350ppm in less than a decade - if we manage grasslands correctly.

text: Your assertion that we must take action to mitigate climate change is based on the belief that there is no change of climate that is naturally occurring.Â  Yes we are putting CO2 in the atmosphere.Â  Yes we are observing climate change.Â Â It does not automatically follow that CO2 causes the climate to change.Â  Climate has been shown to change before the Industrial Age.Â  Therefore CO2 in the atmosphere may not cause climate change.Â  Forecasts of doom only a few years away have been made for a very long time.Â  They have been consistently wrong.Â  I am not advocating that we should not look at cleaner technology.Â  I'm only advocating that there is no reason to panic.Â  When cleaner technology approaches the cost of existing tech(fossil fuels), it will be widely adopted.Â  When it becomes cheaper, it will take over completely.

text:
The minimum global forest cover percentage was in 1912. We have more trees and other photosynthesizing plants now than at any time since. 
https://psmag.com/environment/the-planet-now-has-more-trees-than-it-did-35-years-ago

Most environmental groups only talk about the total amount of trees harvested in a given year to make it seem like we're in dire straits. But of course, like Matt said, it's all about money and the eco groups need to make things look scary to get donations. 

Truth is, the reason we have so many trees today is because logging companies adopted long-term plans to increase the forest cover. Makes sense that a company that relies on trees being around would want to make sure there are plenty of trees in bio-diverse forests. 
https://www.nippon.com/en/ncommon/contents/japan-data/213859/213859.png

Thing is, they use the term "carbon capture" to evoke images of soot and smoke and smog. But it's nice, invisible carbon dioxide. And what do plants need a lot of? Carbon dioxide for photosynthesis! It's literally a greenhouse gas because it's added to greenhouses to help the plants grow better. If you look at satellite images over the last 50 years, the planet keeps getting greener because there's more CO2 for the plants. 

This is nothing more than an expensive, complicated solution to a non-problem.

text:
Planting enough trees to offset the amount of carbon emissions from other sources is entirely unsustainable. With a growing world population, land is needed for agriculture to keep up with food demands. At the same time, energy demands increase and a huge percentage of the global population is still living without electricity, clean water and sufficient food supplies. Why should we deny them basic needs while there are options such as CCS available? 3rd world countries are unlikely to afford cleaner energy, so the likes of coal/gas/oil power plants may be necessary during their industrial revolution.
Additionally, the majority of the worlds power is generated from coal, oil and gas and power plants have lifespans of up to 50+ years. In order for us to keep up with energy demands and limit emissions, fitting CCS onto these plants is essential.

text: SeanGS Based on current energy demand and current available technologies, there is no choice but to continue using fossil fuels in the short term. Renewable energy coming from the likes of wind and solar only produce energy when natural conditions allow and electricity storage technologies do not allow for it to currently be stored long term. Replacing fossil fuels with cleaner ones (such as hydrogen replacing natural gas) will require widespread change to infrastructure. Changes are happening but not at quick enough a pace. We will likely exceed current carbon emissions targets and then have to remove carbon from the atmosphere by using biofuels paired with CCS, for example.

text:
Another video missing the mark completely. You can keep improving your carbon capture technologies as much as you want. The reason they will not pan out is because of plain simple chemistry, physics, logistics and ultimately economics.

Let's take a tonne (1000 kg) of thermal coal as an example. When combusted, that 1 ton of coal results in about 2.86 tons of carbon dioxide (2,860 kg). This is because coal is mostly carbon atoms bonded with hydrogen atoms. Combustion is an oxidation reaction which will bond those carbon atoms with 2 oxygen atoms. So each CO2 compound will now have a molar mass of 44 vs carbon on its own of just 12.

But it gets worse. Not only do you have to deal with almost three-times the mass but it's also now a gas that must be cooled and compressed in order to be transported. This requires energy and enormous amounts of infrastructure.

Now think of all the mines and drill sites that are extracting oil, coal and natural gas all over the world. Think of the major engineering and costs that are required these days to extract those commodities.

Now multiply the mass involved by three,  change the substance into a gas that must be compressed in order to be transported, and try to run that whole system in reverse - Pumping CO2 back into the ground. Think of the massive costs and engineering required.

That's why it won't work. Not because it's hard to extract the CO2 from the plant's smoke stack. But because it would be way way cheaper if we just didn't combust the fossil fuel in the first place than it is to put its CO2 back into the ground after doing it or transforming it into a useful material.

Carbon capture is definitely possible. But economically storing it? You'd likely have to double or triple the cost of the fuel to pay for the infrastructure to put the CO2 back. And if you do that then you'd quickly find that it's cheaper to not burn it at all and find alternative sources of energy than to implement carbon capture.

You're much better off enacting a carbon tax on your economy and letting businesses and society find all the cheap, easy, low-hanging-fruit abatement measures.

author: nyc-n-y

text:
1. Carbon capture from fossil fuel plants is a BAD idea. Coal is on the way out, and every dollar put into capturing carbon from the flues of those plants is a dollar better invested in something else, such as renewable energy or better efficiency. The same is true for gas, to a somewhat reduced degree. A big problem with gas is that the plants are generally much smaller, so it's a non-starter there as well. BTW I'm assuming we're electrifying transportation IAC, so it's just a question of what kind of electricity generation plants to use. Carbon capture from ICE vehicles is obviously not feasible.

2. Direct air capture is a GOOD idea. In fact, it's going to have to happen, and on a huge scale. But it shouldn't be ramped up much until renewables are the dominant energy source. Otherwise, the expense will slow the transition to those renewables, while at the same time facilitating continued use of coal.

Direct air capture needs to mostly be done with machines. A lot of this could possibly be driven by waste heat from industrial operations. IAC this can be scaled up to the necessary levels. This is not true of BECCS, planting trees, or other biologically based solutions, all of which require too much land, and possibly too much labor as well, and are likely to have a variety of other environmental effects as well. Air capture machines can be set up using very little land, possibly even underground. This is a huge advantage.

3. Incorporating CO2 into concreteâ€”hmmm, sounds interesting. I had not heard of this idea before. But I wonder if it could be done on enough of a scale to lock up a large part of the existing CO2 excess. If anyone has extra information, I'm interested.

text:
The "using Carbon Capture & Sequestion (CCS) to cure concrete and reduce CO2"  is silly.  Let's think about this.  When you take limestone, you cook it by burning natural gas, producing, CO2 which goes into the air.  CO2, in the limestone is driven out, leaving calcium.  Thus, more CO2 added to the air.  Then you mix up the concrete, and as it cures, it pulls CO2 out of the air.  Net no change, except the CO2 spent to heat the limestone in the first place.

If we use CCS CO2, to cure concrete, then CO2 is NOT taken out of the air to cure it.  But wait, you had to spend energy (presumably from oil), to move that CCS CO2 to the concrete to be cured.  So this idea is worse than useless.

If you want to lower the CO2 emissions from concrete, bake the limestone with nuclear power (say using electric resistance heating).  That would actually accomplish something.

Warm regards, Rick.

text:
I actually spent 5 yrs of my life researching (i.e. in the actual lab) carbon capture, back when it was called CCS - carbon capture and sequestration (at a conference I went to they said we should stop using sequestration as it is too fancy of a word for the general public to understand). We worked with a lot of the big (and small) companies in this field and even got a $8M DARPA grant for our work.

Here's the problem, most carbon capture technology uses an amine solvent (like MEA, monoethanolamine) to capture CO2. You then have to desorb the CO2 by heating it to high temperatures, which takes a lot of energy and then compress it for storage, which also takes a lot of energy. The models we and others developed showed about half the power generated in a typical coal fired power plant would go to the CO2 capture and compression. We worked with enzymes to accelerate the CO2 capture and reduce the amount of energy needed but even in our best case scenario it would still require about 30% of the power plant's energy output.

Then the question is what are you going to do with the CO2? Sure you can use it for enhanced oil recovery or pump it into abandoned oil wells, but that really only works in Texas. Pumping CO2 from, say, Nebraska to Texas is energy intensive. One big earthquake could release all that CO2 and cause massive deaths (it's happened before, see Lake Nyos disaster). You can pump it to the bottom of the ocean where the weight of the water above will keep CO2 in a liquid state and at the bottom, but again that takes significant energy (bottom of the ocean is ~ 15,000 psi). CO2, energy wise, is bottom of the barrel (it's fully oxidized), so there's not many uses for it at the scale we're talking about. Remember, the scale of CO2 capture is HUGE.

Capturing CO2 from the air is just a stupid idea. As you said the concentration is so low in the atmosphere that the driving force is almost zero. The flux (transfer) of CO2 from the air to the liquid capture solvent is proportional to the driving force, this means it would require huge capture towers to make any difference, and these take massive amounts of energy to run and significant capex to build. The MIT thing may work in the lab and will make a good paper, but is not scalable. You can't override the laws of physics and chemistry, no matter how good you are. The only way anything meaningful will work is to capture it at the point of generation, i.e. coal (or natural gas) fired power plants (there's over 350 in the US and probably 5 times that in the rest of the world).

To sum it up, there is nothing technically difficult about capturing CO2. The problem is you have to essentially build an extra power plant for each existing one just to provide the energy for CO2 capture and compression, which means you have to burn twice the amount of coal you're burning now. And then you have to figure out what you're going to do with it. Just doesn't make a lot of sense. Reduction (population control?) and renewables make more sense.

(FYI, I have a B.S. in chemical engineering and a Ph.D. in Biochemical Engineering)
author: sjn 72

text:
The problem with carbon capture is that it takes energy, and it has to be clean energy for it to help. We get better emissions reduction by just using that clean energy to burn less fossil fuels.

There are still two applications, the first is to offset emissions where we can't avoid them, like in concrete production and air travel, where we just don't have a good solution for zero carbon operations, and we may not be able to find a good solution. 

The second, is to reverse the damage we've done after we have enough clean sources of power. We can run carbon capture at off-peak hours, when power stations would otherwise be idle, and do some very real mitigation of the climate catastrophe.

Both of these use cases require us to go all in on sustainable energy first, and build out whatever carbon capture infrastructure is appropriate second. We should be in the research and pilot program stage of the technology, while solar, wind, and batteries should be in the mass scale manufacturing stage.

Wind and solar are not viable replacement because they do not offer stable energy generation and there is no good way of storing the energy they produce.
author: GeorgeMonet

text:
Â @GeorgeMonetÂ  "Maybe" nuclear vs "certainly" 18th century "technology" of burning coal ?!?
Nuclear is a no-brainer, except for high capex and unfavorable public opinion (carefully nurtured by fossil fuel lobby).
That said, off-shore wind and solar on unproductive land are each more than sufficient. What we need is continental scale grids, and EU is starting with that. Somebody here mentioned  the situation where, for example, south of Germany must rely on gas peakers while north exports excess wind power to Denmark which ships it on to Norway which stores it in their pumped hydro "batteries", with the path reversing at peak times. Intra-German lines would solve this. An underwater cable is being constructed to connect Irish wind with Spanish solar, and both to French nuclear. When hydro and some wind does not suffice in my Croatia, we import French nuclear - Danish and British wind are too far with the current transmission infrastructure.
There is no "one size fits all" solution, but fossil fuels certainly don't fit anything.

text: And that's the problem with technological silver bullets. Technology doesn't replace energy. You can't ignore the law of conservation of energy in the closed system that is Earth. The only solution is to stop consuming and shift entire industry to production of renewable power plants.
author: pafnucek

text: Â @pafnucekÂ  The only real option is reducing consumption and limiting population growth. Sure hydroelectric is great, if you have a fast flowing river nearby and ignore the environmental impact of the dams. Solar requires massive surface area and the commensurate amount of solar panels (which have their own carbon footprint to make and install and have a limited lifetime). Biofuels have a long ways to go and still require huge land masses with the required water and fertilizer and the logistics to transfer all the bio-feedstocks to the fermentation plants. Algae shows a little bit of promise, but again you need large areas and water to grow the algae, then you have to separate all the water from the algae and recover the oil, which is really the achilles heal of algae tech.
author: sjn 72

text: Â @sjn 72Â  Well, to be honest, by saying "solution" I was overly optimistic here. I don't claim it will solve the crysis, especially when we already likely passed the tipping points. But I was saying that in contrast to pipe dream of CCSes. If we don't have political will to shift most of the world industry to serve transition to renewables, regardless how unachievable the ideal of 0 emissions is, and curb our rampant consumption, we are done here. All forms of energy production have problems, because by increasing the energy porfolio even by renewables you enable and stimulate, within the capitalist system, more resource extraction and production. It's called energy-production interface. I don't really see solution to climate change within capitalist system. When it comes to overpopulation and overconsumption, lets remember that the latter results in way higher emissions than the former. Despite record population growth, the poorest countries have the lowest carbon footprint, so I think we should be very careful about population control, when average American produces 14 tons of CO2 a year while average Indian 1.7.

author: pafnucek

text:
Â @Bruno MaillyÂ  You've not worked with algae if you think engineering them is relatively easy. I can think of half a dozen algae companies that are now out of business as they couldn't solve the algae problem. I'm also not sure what you mean by "Both processes are fairly common in various life forms." regarding concentrating and releasing oil.

Besides, concentrating and releasing the oil is not, and doesn't solve, the problem. The oil is already concentrated within the algae and you now have to separate the algae from copious amounts of water. You can't skim them off the top (they grow several feet deep in water) and centrifugation is not easy when their density is similar to that of water (and centrifugation at that scale is not free opex and capex wise). Filter presses don't work all that well for this either. I've seen drum dryers used but, again, these are costly to operate when you're trying to make a commodity chemical (water has a very high heat capacity).
author: sjn 72

text: Â @Bruno MaillyÂ  I don't know much about this, but any capture technology not done at the point of generation (meaning coal or natural gas fired power plants) won't be effective. The concentration of CO2 in the air is just so low that the driving force (essentially the force pushing CO2 from the gas phase to the solid phase) is just miniscule.

text:
I'm not a scientist but, I do know that as the human population increases exponentially, so will the need for oxygen.  That means we're going to need more photosynthetic organisms that depend upon Co2 in order to produce more oxygen.  Maybe "scrubbing" Co2 from the atmosphere is not such a smart idea?  

But, hey....I'll play along.  So, let's assume that every country in the world manages to achieve net zero carbon emissions.  Then what?  What's the plan after that?  Does the planet begin to cool?  Will the Earth's temperature just stop in place and not get warmer or cooler?  Will the climate suddenly become static and stop changing?   If we achieve a net zero carbon footprint, what's the plan after that?  

If you're a scientist, then you know that in order for all efforts to reduce Co2 to be valid, there must be a plan.  If there is no answer to the questions outlined above, then,  there is no plan.  In other words, no one knows what will happen.    If no one knows what will happen, then, how can the push to reduce Carbon and Co2 emission be a scientifically valid plan?  Short answer, its not.  

Also, since when does Co2 alone have sufficient force effect to change the climate?

text:
Â @AKA SGSVirgilÂ  Yes you're not a scientist, nor you have any idea of science or nature, which is basically ok. But please don't be so arrogant to think the scientists does not think or know about the stuff they are saying while you know so little yourself.
First i want to critisise the bascic thinking behind your questions. THE EARTHS NATURE DOES NOT NEED MANKIND TO SUBSTAIN! We should think about the planet like we were some kind of guest. 

To come to speak about your questions regarding CO2 cycle. There are a lot of so called CO2 Sinks and Sources in Nature. The Sinks consume some CO2 burying it into ground and thus removing it from atmosphere. Shells for example. The Sources give CO2 to the atmosphere. Mostly geoloical processes like volcanos or erosion. The Sinks and sources pretty much balance each other out over thousands to millions of years, making concentration shifts very very slow. The CO2 in the air mainly is cycled around though all liveforms. Plants consume sunenergy and CO2 from the air to create the sugar (C6H12O6) etc they are living from. If another liveform (or the plant itself) the consumes this sugar, the sugar will be 'burned' with oxygen into CO2 and H2O, which is the released into the air. 
Your body for example burns about 1kg of carbonhydrates and fat a day and releases 1,6kg CO2 via your lungs a day, which then can again be consumed by plants, and then you can eat the plants again. 

To come to your questios regarding geological time periots. Yes earth cooled and heated often in the millions of years. Ths is a very slow process which is mainly driven by the average CO2 concentration over the times. The drving factors here are the CO2 Sinks and Sources. When the Sinks consume more CO2 then Sources produce, the CO2 concentrations sinks making earth cooler. If the sources are stonger than the sinks, CO2 concentrations rises making earth hotter. This processes are very dependent to the live on earth. The Sinks are mostly based on some organic activety. When now the sinks are strong they cool the earth down reducing their own activity. At a tipping point the sinks are getting so weak that the sources are bigger, thus again increasing the CO2 concentration, warming the climate, and again making the sinks stronger again. Constant and very very slow up and down. 

Now you could think, when CO2 rate is chaning since all the time, why do we care? The reason is not the change itself, the reason is how fast this change happens. Nature can adopt to it's climate enviroment, but this takes hundrets of thounsands of years. Currently we see a change that fast, it nerver happens bevor in the history of our planet, creating big dangers for a giant amount of nature, which we are dependet of. Think about youre self driving in a car. Not the Speed is important, but the change of speed. Driving 60m/h / 100km/h 33m/s is no problem. Breaking on the corse of 100m is also no Problem, since the changing rate is only 10km/h per 10 Meter which is fine. But crashing into a wall, making the change rate to 100km/h per 0m will kill you. Just to demonstrate that not the level, concentration or speed is the problem, but the chaning rate 

And now at last, why has CO2 an impact on the climate in the first place. We have to dig a bit into electromagnatic radiation for that. Probaly you know light is electromagnetic radiation. If radiation hits matter 3 things can happen. 1st. It can get absorbed, converting the energy of the radiation into atom vibrating. The rate a atom vibrates gives it's temperature, since this vibrating and temperature is basically the same. 2nd. It can be reflected, the radiation then just bounces away into another direction. 3th. It can be passed through, then the radiation just dont interfere with the matter, making this matter transparent for this radiation. 
I'll give you some examples. Your body my friend is for example are Case 1 and 2 for the visible spectrum of electromagnetic radiation called light. Thats why i could see you, the light refelcts back into my eye, and you can feel light on your skin. The lights energy gets partly absorbed creating the heat you can feel. 
Now example for X-Rays which are electromagnetic radiation as well. For them your body is almost transparent case 3 which is why you barly can see your body on a X-Ray Pic. Your bodys bones on the other hand are different, the radiation gets absorbed and relected, making them visible. 
I could now basically give endless examples. Important for you to know is that any material, gasses as well will absorb, reflect or passthrough some are of the electromagnetic radiaton spectrum. 
And now finally we are at why atmospheric CO2 heats the earth. Most heat is caused by the area of the electromagnetic radiation called infrared. This is just below the spectrum humans can see. CO2 absorbes this spectrum to almost 100%. I told you, absorbtion heats stuff. The CO2 molecules in air get hotter, and sharing their excess heat with the rest of the air. 
The earth recives energy from the sun as light and other areas of the electromagnetic spectrum. Stuff that got a lot of energy wants to get rid of this extra energy, often via the emitting of exact that infrared radiation. This energy normaly radiates then away into space. Partly it got absorbed by Clouds and CO2 which is dependnt from the concentration of both. 
And now finally we're at the problem. Mankind rises the concentration of CO2 in atmosphere, making it more opaque for infrared radiation, trapping that as heat in earths energy system. This is then compensated by the melting of polar ice which cooles the system as long as there is enough ice avaible. But as soon as there is not enough ice anymore the heat will acumulate very quick. 
Just like a glas of coke with icecubes inside. As long there is ice inside, it can sit in the sun and keeps cold pretty good, but when all ice is gone, it's not drinkable anymore very very quick. Probably you've experienced that your self. 
You can also do a very easy experiment with that: 
Glass coke in the sun with ice. Note every minute the temperature in the glass. As long there is ice, the temperature will rise barly, but as soon there is no ice anymore, temperature will skyrocket.
This melting of polar ice is called a tipping point. Thats because ice reflects a lot of radiation recived from sun directly back into space. But if the ice is gone, the suns radiation hits liquid water, which does not relect but absorb almost 100% of that radiation, making it hotter, meltung more ice, exposing more water.... endless till there is no ice. 

Hope that helped. If you want to know more, just read wikipedia. If you only need basic understanding it's more than enough. And as well i can recoment www.skepticalscience.com which is directly related to the climate topic, explaing maybe even more questions regarding climate you have.

text: I worked in a different industry and hold several patents.  You are very intelligent person and would be an asset to a company. Caveat: I am simplifying the next statement a lot:   Back in the 70's, they said the smallest line we could make was 193nm.  Because the laws of physics said that was wavelength of energy we could create that would still affect opaque materials. There are solutions out there.  We just need to find them.

1) you need to stop pushing your ideology into the discussion. Anything that you think you need to force people to do with "political will" is wrong to begin with. I live in a country which is always threatened by socialism and you wouldn't last one month in here.

2) no matter how much your "political will" destroys your own economy, China is not going to stop polluting the same planet you live in. All you get with your "political will" is becoming even more trapped in the "political will" of the CCP. They made billions with "vaccines" and "ventilators" from their own god damm virus. They were going to pull the same fast one in the world with that crap Paris agreement. Even after signing it they still kept building one new COAL plant every two weeks.

3) the population of Nigeria is not going to stop growing and you can't force them to. Feminism will not destroy their families like it did to ours for at least the next 20 years, so you are just going to be demographically replaced in the world and not solve any of the environmental problems you pretend to be concerned with.

4) climate fear mongers like you never talk about our main source of energy besides Earth's core: the sun. The sun has cycles of high and low activity and Earth's orbit also changes in cycles. For a large part of the 20th century, the planet received a low input of energy. The low temperatures and ice storms killed the crops in the South of my country and forced people to move to the center-west. Only recently it has recovered. Before that, in the 1700s (if I am not mistaken) a cycle of low activity caused one of the greatest famines in Europe. Just like CO2 itself, heat is great for FOOD PRODUCTION.

5) the lobby against nuclear power and for solar and wind is just as bad as the lobby for oil. In fact, did you know that due to the unreliability of solar and wind you need to have a gas plant together with them? So it is literally the same lobby. Oil pays for solar and wind propaganda. Meanwhile we already have technology for consuming nuclear waste to generate more power and less dangerous nuclear waste and modular molten salt reactors which are inherently safe against meltdowns. But that never gets any attention because it doesn't allow to make bombs. India is one of the biggest countries in the world and is developing their own Thorium-based nuclear energy programs.

6) we have had recent breakthroughs of supercritical CO2 turbines. This is huge and I see very little news about it. These turbines can recover energy from low temperature systems in just about every industry, and can improve the efficiency of any power plant.

7) one of the biggest CO2 recycling systems of the biosphere is cyanobacteria. They use solar energy and sea water. If we want to remove CO2 from the atmosphere, why not use them?

text:
Â @Mario BrosÂ 
"climate fear mongers like you never talk about our main source of energy besides Earth's core: the sun"
Because it is irrelevant, the sun's output is very stable in such short time span as a couple of centuries. Also, it's decreasing now, but again: irrelevant.

"Before that, in the 1700s (if I am not mistaken) a cycle of low activity caused one of the greatest famines in Europe"
So called "little ice age", but the change in temperature was about the same as warming since the industrial revolution until now, and the worst of it is still ahead of us.

"Meanwhile we already have technology for consuming nuclear waste to generate more power and less dangerous nuclear waste and modular molten salt reactors which are inherently safe against meltdowns"
There is currently exactly zero MSRs in operation, China is building 2 (I think India is also building some), results can be expected by earliest 2025 and 2035. Most likely too late in the fight against climate change (remember: another 5-10 years to build a reactor), even if they end up working in large scale. I hope it will turn out great but would rather not bet humanity's future on it. Breeder reactors using nuclear waste are just commercially even less viable than conventional nuclear plants (more expensive per energy). I'm ok with that, but climate change is not a technological problem at first: it's economical and political. We have solutions but only expensive ones, and those are usually stuck at the "and who will pay for it?" question.

"But that never gets any attention because it doesn't allow to make bombs."
I think you mean Thorium, but it can and has been made into bombs. There is no way around nuclear proliferation, accept it or forget nuclear power.

text:

Not only is nuclear safe it can run 24/7 at the same power level unlike the acres and acres of crappy wind mills and solar panels.
author: 1320crusier

text:
Â @1320crusierÂ  Safe, because we invested the time, regulatory oversight, and money into them.

And running at the same power level 24/7 is a disadvantage, not an advantage. Peak power demand is usually in the mid-late afternoon. A nuclear plant cannot handle the difference in demand between 4pm and 4am. Wind turbines can, because they have brakes that can throttle down to zero power without any danger, and solar pv can do effectively the same with a flip of a switch. Nuclear reactors get xenon poisoning, taking hours to purge to safely restart.

And nuclear energy costs twice as much as solar or wind, the US EIA estimates a cost of $81.65/mWh for "advanced nuclear", while they estimate $39.95 for wind, and $35.74/mWh for solar pv. 

https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/aeo/pdf/electricity_generation.pdf

See table 1b, on page 7 for the figures.

Nuclear power just is not economically viable, and any new technology that might be economically viable isn't going to be ready for industrial scale production in time to deal with climate change. Sure, keep working on them, build an experimental reactor or two if the new tech looks promising, but stop pretending it is relevant to the current crisis, because it just isn't.

text:
Madness is rare in individuals - but in groups, parties, nations, and ages it is the rule. Friedrich NietzscheÂ 
Tell us, Matt, how much did the oil cartel pay you to foster this foolish fiction?  Throughout your presentation you ASSUME that carbon dioxide is inherently harmful. Would you kindly explain HOW it is harmful? That will be a good trick, because carbon dioxide is inert, benign, beneficial, and ESSENTIAL FOR LIFE! Every cell in the body manufactures carbon dioxide, and the human body contains about 20 liters of carbon dioxide that is absorbed in fluids and tissues, as compared to one liter of oxygen and one liter of nitrogen. If the stuff were toxic, we would all be dead. CO2 is essential for oxygen oxygen capture from the atmosphere and transport to cells deep within the vertebrate body. It lowers capillary flow resistance, and promotes cardiac output and tissue perfusion. It has no more toxic effects than water. One can drown in carbon dioxide, just as one can drown in water, but it has no toxic effects on tissues. In short, all this noise about carbon dioxide is just that---NOISE. It stinks of ignorance and malicious mischief. It's expecially ridiculous when one considers that cancer, diabetes, hypertension, asthma,rheumatoid diseases, and chronic illnesses of all sorts were rare 100 years ago, are rising catastrophically in accord with toxic environmental pollution from automobile exhaust, chlorinated water, pesticides, herbicides, and toxic industrial wastes. Anyone interested in the facts might begin with my essay called "Four Forgotten Giants of Anesthesia History" that is published on the Internet and can be accessed free of charge. www.stressmechanism.com.

text: So the reason they don't want to work with trees is because before investing in a large market, a business needs to prove to their stockholders that they control enough of the market so that no one will come in and undercut the market, and they lose all the money they invested.  One way they do that is by only funding highly technical projects where the barrier to entry is so high that they are unlikely to get any competitors.  Another way is by owning key patents that make it very expensive for anyone else to compete with them without large amounts of research and development.  In a low tech market they do a lot of research in production and transportation techniques to reduce their costs so that no one can afford to do what they are doing with lower maintenance costs.  Think of injection molding, there is simply no cheaper way to manufacture many things than injecting plastic in a mold, that is why most of what we own contains plastic, not wood.  The closest they can come is die stamping, but that doesn't work for more complicated shapes.  If you could either make very cheap plastic out of wood or come up with a tree planting process that couldn't be duplicated by your competitor cheaper, then we would have a lot more trees.  With all the fires in California, make sure you plant these orchards somewhere that never gets very low humidity.  The simple answer is, trees have such a low barrier to entry that investing in them would be unstable.  Investors don't like unstable.

You probably wouldn't last the day unless you keep your head down and beg god to keep you alive.  You do not want the real climate crisis in your lifetime, but if you are under 40, you will probably get the real crisis.  And there is nothing you can do to prepare.  People are smart, they will find you.  Anything you could possibly do to "outsmart" them, trust me, they thought of that too.  Even if you have an underground bunker, they will find you.  Even if you can't imagine how they could possibly find your bunker, they will.  There are millions of people smarter than you, and they will come up with a simple method of fishing out bunkers. Very simple, this solution is permanent, planting trees is temporary.
All carbon captured by a tree during it's lifecycle is used as building blocks to grow. Thus when the tree dies all that carbon can be released again either by rotting or burning the wood. text: The funny thing is that nature is kind of doing that itself.  If you consider that most of North America used to be covered by kilometers of ice, and since it has melted, vegetation is growing where ice once was.  If you go far enough north you will run into the tree line which is caused by the permafrost in the ground not allowing tree roots to grow.  When the permafrost thaws, the boreal spans further north.  New trees take CO2 and convert it into the biomass of the tree and so on.  It's like... nature has its own checks and balances and the current level of CO2 and future projections of CO2 are not unprecedented in earths history.  The fossil fuels we use are literally the hydrocarbon remains from life that got buried there.  When they're used, they're getting thrown back into the earths budget

text: Trees capture carbon, but then dump it back into the environment when they're done. Trees use carbon to build support material. They don't convert carbon into oxygen. They store it. Global warming is measured in spans of thousands of years, which is greater than the lifespan of a tree, meaning it'll capture its carbon, then dump it back and the environment will proceed like nothing happened. On a more short-term span of time, they use carbon to create leaves. Leaves fall off in autumn and are gobbled by microbes and turned back into atmospheric carbon. In short, best case scenario is they do nothing. Worst-case is they become kindling for forest fires.

text:
I'm going to reply to this comment as it seems to have the liveliest discussion under this video.
Disclaimer - to anyone - really just want to help with the discussion, but I think there are some major misconceptions about trees and the CO2 cycle as well as maybe some ideas missing in this discussion.

1 - dont look at the single tree. Yes when it dies it will rott away and release co2 again. But a forest as a whole is CO2 negative. CO2 will be stored in the roots, funghi, animals ... and the layers of fallen leaves eg. will not just rott away into CO2 again, but will actually build up soil and bind it that way too - like the initial oil / coal build up we use today.

2 - We have enough land. I really don't want to start a vegan/vegetarian discussion, BUT 50% of useable land today is used for agriculture, of which ~80% are used directly for livestock or to feed such. We need to take this on. When everyone at least reduces we can free so much land for reforestation.

3 - forests grow themselves. Not much to add, but yes we can help that by spreading seeds further, but there's allready tech - look at drones, seedbombs etc.

4 - a tree does not have to be grown out until it stores CO2. A Tree (or generally speaking a plant) is made up of nearly 100% Carbon. Even while they are growing they are storing Carbon away from the atmosphere.

5 - We can use water surfaces as well. Algae can decalcify water, grows rapidly and just needs a 'hook' to grow on. Over deep sea this can be achieved by floating constructions. When they've grown long enough, they can be cut down, sink to the bottom of the sea floor where the water pressure traps the CO2. There are also Tests with algae trapping CO2 on land (very successful - search eg for Paris), turning them into food, building materials etc, or best one: Algae which produce Oil which resembles Oil used for Transportation in any fashion (Car, Plain, Ship) - this by it self would provide net-zero-emission energy source fueled by sunlight without the need to replace current technologies / motors with electrical ones (It's not the car itself thats damaging to the environment, it's the fuel)

6 - Reduce. I know it's not really part of the discussion, but when we discuss about the net-sums of how much equivalent of CO2 we have to store in trees for which time compared to capture the CO2-output of factories etc. - please don't forget, one of the easiest way to help the environment is to reduce the output of CO2 in the Beginning. I really believe that as a human / worldwide society we should prioritize what we need. And we really should make these most basic and necessary things as environmentally-friendly as possible. Home (earth) - food - shelter - energy - education - transportation - ... and then fill in by prio and possibility. Adjust the economy to this then, not the other way around. 

We all don't need to work 40 hrs/week to buy things we don't need to keep a economy of unlimited growth running which is killing ourselves. The Planet and life in general here will survive - will we?
And sustainability in simple terms means that we should be able to do something in the same kind of fashion for ... ever. A sustainable earth is possible when everyone lives a 1960's swiss lifestyle.

Please correct me where I'm wrong, fill in the blanks, add more ideas, we can only do this together :)

Â @Brin JenkinsÂ    Totally agree.  We could send the children to the fields to grow food before their 10th birthdays.  Or we can have the luxury of reliable energy supplies which allows people to reach the levels of education required to support an advanced economy. 
What does reliable energy supply give us....
It allows people to stay in education into their 30's to give us the medics and surgeons we need for long life expectancy
It allows people to stay in education into their  mid 20's to give us the microbiologists and chemists we need for a pharmaceutical industry
It allows people to stay in education into their mid 20's to give us the engineers and technologists we need for industrial production, including transportation, food production and the information age
It allows people to stay in education into their mid 20's to give us the lawyers and accountants we need for an advanced bureaucracy where we have the luxury of personal possession and the protection of the rule of law
It's easy to turn your nose up with "yeah yeah, clean diesel, clean coal".  But that's a sign of the assumptions that can be made from living a comfortable life with plentiful supply of energy. The alternative is brutal and bleak. In the fields by your 10th birthday and you'd be lucky to see your grandchildren.

text:
Â @Glenn ReidÂ  I'm terms of the pressure within the actual ducting as it travels down I have no idea, it'd depend on the material and diameters they were using, whatever seals they were using to stop reversal etc.

But in terms of what pressure carbon dioxide would need to be stored at in terms of mostly raw CO2 that you're not doing anything special to (Think using cerium as a catalyst to remove the oxygen atoms etc), would be somewhere in the region of between 1000 - 1200 psi. If you can get it below about 900 meters, say 1km to be conservative you can keep it in a supercritical fluidy type state indefinitely just by the natural psi down there is within that range. Now sequestration is NOT the smoking gun solution, it's certainly pricey and you'd get best results by finding areas that are seismically stable but that don't present a challenge in boring down too much, which is why the North Sea is pretty promising.

Im no economist, it may transpire that trying to decarbonise goods, services and energy is cheaper in the long run, but I'll bet that over the next 20-30 years that won't be able to happen fast enough and we'll use sequestration as a stop gap solution in part until we get there.

I now have no hope left for our civilization to continue and am truly fearing our complete extinction in the not so distant future. 
 At this point in time we have only one hope or chance to save ourselves from a terrible future. This would involve completely changing our way of life and goals in all countries in the world very very quickly. Here's some of the things I think we'd need:
  1- Change the money system into a CO2 equivalent value system instead of gold, oil or governments as it's backing 
  2- Change all prices on every goods and services into CO2 equivalent prices (figuring out how much CO2 is released by the particular product's construction, manufacturing or growing technique.)

  4- Constructing on existing roads an electrified train service for essential travel and movement of goods.
Â  5-Close all non essential manufacturing including planes, cars, trains, computers, TVs, you name it unless absolutely necessary for life close it down.( making it mandatory to repair anything which is made for as long as possible)
  6-Having local areas as self-sustaining and governing as possible.
   7-Educating all children in science, math, literature and our new philosophy so they may understand why these steps where necessary.
  8-Refusing to trade with any nations which do not comply and actively trying to force them to comply.
  9-Having one world body in charge of trade, CO2 counting for the currency which would be monitored by local governments.
 10-Having few laws on personal behavior and more on environmental conduct and damage enforced by local governments.
 11-Promoting fruit and vegetable gardening and volunteering.
 12-Reducing the work week as to share the work load across the citizens.
 13-Have a merit based higher education system for research and work on expanding our knowledge in Universities to push our scientific knowledge and have that knowledge freely available to the public and other institutions.
 14-Have a basic amount of CO2 credits to all people with no one allowed to use more than they have.( This would allow some who chose to save theirs to trade them with others who need more. Credits would be issued weekly to all people and extra would be earned at work like regular money but with a 8 hr work week. The weekly credit would be enough to feed you and 1/2 a child with housing and utilities. Growing food, volunteering and working would provide extra credits. Saving credits wouldn't be possible therefore no need for any banking.

Just a ruff draft I'd love to see refinements from others please.

text:
You capture 100% of the carbon you don't burn...
 
Snarky comment aside, I think this is a great technology... for pulling CO2 out of the atmosphere and providing precursors to materials and synthetic fuels. We should really be aiming to stop burning fossil fuels entirely (and probably not burn too much biomass either), though CCUS on flue gases might help minimise the impact from gas power until we have better demand/supply management and can shut them down. There's no excuse to still be burning coal, though, and my country hasn't burned any for months.
 
Ultimately, we need everything we can throw at this problem. Insulating buildings, installing solar panels, nuclear baseload/peaking capacity, energy storage, domestic heat pumps, battery electric vehicles, hydrogen as fuel/storage... With everything, including CCUS to pull out the carbon we've already put into the atmosphere, we might stand a chance.

text: Just thinking about this in the simplest possible way, the ONLY way to slow down and reverse climate change is to removed carbon from the atmosphere. The carbon from fossil fuels was happily locked up carbon taken out from the Carboniferous period until we put it back in the atmosphere. The ONLY way to stop its effects on climate is to put it back in the ground. Tree's can't do this unless you cut them down on an industrial scale, bury them and let new ones grow in their place and repeat the process. THis would effectively speed up the natural process. Regardless of the method. The ONLY way to fix this is removing extra carbon from the atmosphere and putting it back in the ground.
author: Joseph Simonsen

text:
Just as usual - a very well researched topic!
On top, Matt has found one of the most important issues in all issues climate change and climate mitigation!
I studied, I did research and I work in this field of expertise. I also had some contact with the Swiss company mentioned in this clip - Climeworks. So what about CCS? Well, it might just be the next bitcoin - depending on what regulators will do. 

From my work, I know that it is always the monetary issues that make one thing work and another won't. It, therefore, comes to no surprise that even the EU is rather slow in getting their act together when it comes to emissions and emission reduction. nZEB is just one example of how many member states slow down the application and water down the goals. In order to just get somewhere into the neighborhood of emissions reduction, we would need a similar emissions reduction as we got from the COVID 19 economical slow down - and this every year. 

So, if we are not able to reduce emissions, we need to capture them. What is the alternative?? Geo-engineering?? That would be real scary stuff which we still do not even have the slightest hint of how that could work and what consequences that concept would have. It is then on the regulator to set prices for emissions as well as max. limits - if you go over the limits, you MUST capture. At the moment the cost per captured CO2 is about US $ 800 - to US $ 900 per ton. The market price is about US $ 200! So there is a big cap - a mandate would increase demand sharply and the market price and the true costs would get much closer. 

It is of utmost importance to have a safe storage concept. Climeworks has one of the best since it is in solid form. Earthquakes and similar are no issue!

text:
