And somewhat temporarily at that, since trees will eventually burn or decompose. 

However that's not to say that there is NO role for trees and other biomass to play. I'm cautiously optimistic about cross laminated timber and hempcrete as alternative building materials that can hopefully store carbon for a long long time. Additionally, there are a lot of other benefits to increasing the amount of greenery in our living spaces . Cooling effects for urban areas, localized food production, etc. The beautiful thing is, we can do those things AND pursue CCUS tech.

text: Â @RedRock CRFÂ  It does not need to be equal to before. All we care about is the total CO2 in the atmosphere. Where the rest goes, does not matter in the grand scheme of things. The idea of creating carbonate minerals to lock CO2 away is quite brilliant. The best of these ideas however is the idea to use CO2 as a raw material in concrete. The human race always needs concrete to build structures, and used concrete is rarely recycled. It mostly ands up in landfills. using captured CO2 as an essential building material would mean that over time, with new construction and the demolition of old construction, the CO2 becomes trapped in rubble in our landfills, never to resurface again.

author: Adam Lytle

text:
Â @Allen LoserÂ  wow, because it's good for one slice of life, it must be good for everything!

That is of course demonstrably false. Cognitive ability in people is affected by CO2 levels not much higher than what we have now, and 1200ppm might explain your comment, I recommend working on some airflow in your house, you need more oxygen.

The argument for renewables is based on the observation of all ecology, not just the things we eat.
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text: Â @Allen LoserÂ  LAWKI has evolved for the current ecosphere. The point is that changing that significantly will result in the end of LAWKI, and I for one think that would be irresponsible simply because we couldn't be bothered.
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text:
Â @Allen LoserÂ  OSHA regulations state that it is safe for exposure, not that it does not negatively affect you, just that there are no long term effects. That's also an 8hr time weighted average, not a 24hr average. More modern studies show that above 1000ppm you have short term impairment of cognition. That's not to say it will negatively harm you permanently, but while you're in that environment it is the case. If the general environment is close to those levels, well then I guess it will be permanent.

As for food, we already have enough, it's just not well distributed. Also, they do produce more yield with higher CO2, as long as you can also increase the water supply they need. I don't think I need to link to the many problems we already have with water supplies in major growing areas, and how increasing that, or how changing the climate might shift where the water is and so destroy the abilility to realise increased yields.

Unless that is you think all of our crops should be grown hydro? Good luck with that.

As for returning carbon to the atmosphere, yes it came from there, but it is also being added by other means. When those means add, and the natural cycle sequester, that's a long term sustainable cycle. When we take what has been sequestered over a hundred million years, and add it back over a couple hundred years (that's 6 orders of magnitude), that's what will lead to the problems that most scientists are warning of today.

I can't read your LAWKI comment, youtube cuts it off, but needless to say the very definition of LAWKI is the current climate, not 200m years ago, not a million in the future. Changing that significantly over the short term will have a significant effect on humanity and the rest of the ecosphere, and get ready for mass migrations when that happens, climate refugees if you will. It's already begun.

author: Josh Priebe

text:
That's a myth.  Trees capture hardly any net carbon in the long run because nearly all of it goes back to the environment.  Pretty much 100% of the net carbon capture is directly measurable as it is basically equal to the mass of the tree.  When you add that up, 1 new tree would take 80 years to capture the total output of a single American's carbon footprint for 1 year.  In other words, an infinite number of trees will do nothing.  You can actually do better with many food and/or industrial crops because their rate of replenishment is fast and the resource consumption for their cultivation can be smaller in relation to the end product.  We'll anyway need to grow more crops to feed a growing population, but as the population grows, so too does energy consumption, so it's not really a solution.

Alternative materials in industrial applications outside of the existing norms can help not so much because they're eliminating greenhouse gases, but because they'd be more efficient on the overall cycle.

author: Putzak

text:
Â @Jordi SauraÂ  I'm not saying that trees won't absorb any CO2.  I'm saying that it will not be significant by any means.  The total greenhouse gas mass that a tree will absorb over its entire life will be no greater than the mean annual per capita carbon footprint for first world nations.  You use the example of trees used for lumber -- they will not absorb much more than 25-30 tons of CO2 before they are cut down -- and it takes decades to get there vs. just one year for a person.  When you speak of enormous massive trees, those are the exceptional individual trees in protected forest land that get up into the thousands of tons.  Those are not a statistically significant contributor and those trees need entire centuries to get that huge.

The myth is not whether or not there is net CO2 absorption...  the myth is that planting new trees is some sort of solution.  It's not.  The net absorption per tree is far too small early on and grows at far too slow of a rate to have any meaningful impact.  You can do better with other tools.
author: Parashar Krishnamachari

text: It's not that easy. Planting wherever, whatever doesn't solve the problem, and can even make it worse. First, you have to plant native trees and maintain diversity, otherwise your plantations are prone to pests and wildfires and are poor habitats for animals. Secondly, planting in most northern latitudes, the boreal forest, decreases albeedo significantly which offsets the carbon storage benefit. What you really need to do is to maintain and expand tropical forests, because they store the most carbon and don't change albeedo in comparison to surrounding vegetation. Now how easy is planting and expanding forests in Congo and Brazil, given the geopolitical situation? Finally, you have to grow food somwhere. Even if you plant entire globe to the state it was in the middle ages it will not counter all our emissions and what the Oceans and permafrost emissions past the tipping point will produce.
